title: <start> what do you think when a client tells you they are suicidal <end>
response: <start> well . . . . my immediate thought is that this person is really suffering and currently in an unhealthy place . people who are healthy neither are actively suicidal or lie about it . i do not really care whether they are lying attention seeking or being completely honest . i make sure to do everything in my power to keep them safe , be that a referral for evaluation for hospitalization or just developing a concrete and detailed safety plan to follow if they start feeling impulsive or as though they may act on their thoughts . if a person is has passive suicidal ideation , i will check in from time to time but continue working with them . if they are frequently actively suicide or on the fence ie . they actually want to kill themselves , are forming plans , took some action at an attempt i am going to refer them to a higher level of care . if our work in therapy is not enough to keep them stable , they really need something more intensive that i can not offer inpatient , partial hospitalization program , intensive outpatient group , debt program if they were indeed honest to god actively suicidal , this will help them get the help they need . if they were lying and attention seeking , they will learn that this is not the appropriate way to get attention , at least not from me , as our relationship will end due to my need to transfer them to a higher level of care . all in all , when i hear these things , i just feel for the client and want to do whatever i can to help them without taking any chances . <end>

title: <start> well . . . . my immediate thought is that this person is really suffering and currently in an unhealthy place . people who are healthy neither are actively suicidal or lie about it . i do not really care whether they are lying attention seeking or being completely honest . i make sure to do everything in my power to keep them safe , be that a referral for evaluation for hospitalization or just developing a concrete and detailed safety plan to follow if they start feeling impulsive or as though they may act on their thoughts . if a person is has passive suicidal ideation , i will check in from time to time but continue working with them . if they are frequently actively suicide or on the fence ie . they actually want to kill themselves , are forming plans , took some action at an attempt i am going to refer them to a higher level of care . if our work in therapy is not enough to keep them stable , they really need something more intensive that i can not offer inpatient , partial hospitalization program , intensive outpatient group , debt program if they were indeed honest to god actively suicidal , this will help them get the help they need . if they were lying and attention seeking , they will learn that this is not the appropriate way to get attention , at least not from me , as our relationship will end due to my need to transfer them to a higher level of care . all in all , when i hear these things , i just feel for the client and want to do whatever i can to help them without taking any chances . <end>
response: <start> to me , this sounds like the right approach as there is a reason why that person would be lying if they are which still deserves some recognition and care . x b i am interested by the idea of attention seeking do you perceive this as a negative thing , that they are in some way manipulating you or that they are looking for help because they need it for whatever reason that is not suicidal feelings <end>

title: <start> to me , this sounds like the right approach as there is a reason why that person would be lying if they are which still deserves some recognition and care . x b i am interested by the idea of attention seeking do you perceive this as a negative thing , that they are in some way manipulating you or that they are looking for help because they need it for whatever reason that is not suicidal feelings <end>
response: <start> attention seeking itself is not a negative thing . every single person alive wants attention , validation , and caring relationships . for many folks , they have learned that one way to get those things is through suicidal gestures . people do what works . the problem is , this is something that works in the short term but causes more long term damage to relationships so it is not something i would want to reinforce . they may be trying to manipulate me , be it consciously or unconsciously half the time they are not even aware that they are not actually suicidal . . . . essentially they have tricked themselves . again , i do not really care . everybody manipulates in some shape or form . as therapists , we are probably the biggest manipulators albeit hopefully for the clients benefit rather than our own . my goal is to help them the best i can with what i determine they need help with . if i think they need help reducing the amount they use suicidal gesturing by manipulation , i am going to do my due diligence to keep them safe but in most cases ultimately , that leads to the ending of our relationship , at least until they are in a place of more stability with less suicidal gestures or ideation . then they will be able to work with me again . <end>

title: <start> my girlfriend is extremely depressed and i am not sure what to say or how to help . urgent . <end>
response: <start> if you have any indication that she is at a risk for harming herself call the suicide hotline . their number is . they will answer anytime of the day or night , days a week . they will talk you through a major crisis and connect you to local resources . if you explain to them that you are a teen and your girlfriend does not have the financial resources for conventional therapy they can help you there . if you have even the slightest inkling that she may hurt herself call the hotline . she can also call herself and ask for help . it is a good resource and they can offer some assistance . you are clearly concerned enough that you have come to reedit for help , so it is worth calling the hotline . it certainly will not hurt . so , this is to say , that calling someone to help is not an a hole move . if you do be prepared that she may not be real happy with you in the moment . she will realize that you are trying to help . have you expressed that you are concerned for her if not , just say something along the lines of i have noticed you have been kind of detached lately . would you be comfortable telling me what is going on in your head when she wanted to talk just listen . does her family other than the aunt you tested know about her struggles has she been in therapy or taken medications previously i hope you can find the resources you need . <end>

title: <start> my therapist ghosted me <end>
response: <start> the situation you describe is actually a therapist violating professional ethics . a therapist literally cannot ghost a client , ethically therapists have a responsibility to provide care or to provide referrals and make a reasonable effort to connect a client with a other therapist . not doing so puts both professional license and professional organization membership at risk . you would be within your rights to review your states doh website and potentially reach out to the doh department of health <end>

title: <start> how can i find a good therapist <end>
response: <start> if you are in america there are a few ways to go about this . i suggest the best way is word of mouth . if you have any friends who see a therapist you could use them as a referral . often therapists schedules will fluctuate whether or not they are taking new clients so it can be tricky . if the therapist is part of a clinic they may refer to another therapist in house . this method may open doors that would otherwise be closed . the only consideration is if the referring friend is a pivotal figure in your life . if so the therapist may consider it a conflict of interest and refer hopefully in house to another therapist . if you have insurance you can call them and they will give you a list of therapists in your network . also , if you are currently working or a dependent of someone who is working they may have employee assistance programs cap which sets a person up with a therapist sessions covered . otherwise , websites like psychologytoday can help you search for therapists and filter for insurance , speciality , and location . lastly , if you are struggling to find someone check out samosa or name . they often have open support groups and you may find one specific to your needs . <end>

title: <start> what is your opinion <end>
response: <start> hey there i am sorry you are feeling so shaken up and upset about this experience . it makes sense that it would spike your anxiety and just generally be really unsettling . i can certainly understand you not wanting to run into people you know in such a vulnerable place . that being said , i would not really expect your therapist to reach out to you before your next appointment to check in on you , based on the events you described . there is a good chance your therapist noticed that you were upset by being confronted by someone you know in the waiting room . however , that is not too uncommon of an occurrence , especially in a smaller town . there is not a whole ton that can be done to prevent people running into someone they know in the waiting room . have you had an appointment with them since the event if so and your therapist did not bring it up , then you will need to be the one to bring it up and figure out if you want to stay with the same therapist from there . if you have not had an appointment since this happened , then i would encourage you to bring it up then . i want to also gently challenge your assumption that your therapist saw that you were upset by bumping into someone in the waiting room . it is very possible that they noticed , but it is also quite possible that they did not . that does not mean they do not care about you , but you may need to be the one to bring it up to them <end>

title: <start> been depressed for years , but i still can not bring myself to do anything about it <end>
response: <start> sometimes it is much easier to talk to a stranger about how you feel than with a friend . a therapist has no bias for or against you . they are there to listen . and you do not have to worry about revealing too much to a person you socialize with . it is a win win . it sounds like you know the answer to your own question already . go talk to someone . you do not have to tell your friends or family anything about it if you are afraid they might judge you they should not , by the way . if you are in college i would bet that you have access to free or affordable counseling . please take advantage of it and help yourself take care . <end>

title: <start> help with my adult daughter with complex ptsd . <end>
response: <start> i hear your worry , and see that you want to help her . i can not give any sort of specific advice , but love and accept her for who she is . your anxiety may because her more anxiety , or make her think you believe her to be incapable or some other unhelpful thought . it is possible that your care and worry can work against her , without realizing it or intending it . be someone who listens and validates her . acknowledge her challenges , and that chronic illness can be difficult . lots of people start with only socializing online , do not judge it , know that she is doing what is safe for her , and when she feels more confident will branch out . i guess my best advice is be nonjudgmental , loving and supportive . provide acknowledgment and validation for her struggles , and know she is doing her best . she needs to be built up in her confidence , and even your concern or true caring can possibly come off as belief that she is incapable unable . lots of well meaning parents do harm unintentionally . i see you mean well and hope this does not come off harsh . you know she is not lazy , she just needs help therapy is definitely the best first step . also , yoga yoga can be very beneficial for trauma and health reasons <end>

title: <start> recovering from intellectualization <end>
response: <start> numbing out feelings is super common , and i personally have been in the recovery process therapists are jacked up too , it is usually why we are therapists . first , to find meaning you have to look for it . start by practicing gratitude , everyday . by the end of the day find three things you are grateful for . they can be as small or big as you choose . for example , i am so grateful for this comfy couch . i am so grateful for my dog , my best friend , this burrito , getting to laugh today , the warm weather , that butterfly . literally anything . it will be easier with time , but will help you find the good in life . next , feelings . you have made an awesome discovery i thought i felt my feelings . i was wrong . you already know you are not feeling them , that is amazing insight . look for what you do when feelings might otherwise be present avoidance tactics are often things like food no food , drugs , sex , excessive video games , excessive sports watching , really anything excessive , things that instantly make you feel good . this will help you recognize numbing techniques . when you know what you are using , you will better recognize when the feelings should be around . notice where you feel things in your body , happy , sad , anger , etc . where is it next time you get that physical feeling , listen , what is it telling you it is really hard work , but this is the beginning . seeing a therapist is the best thing , because you will need individualized care which an internet stranger can not give you , and you will need coping skills once the feelings start coming back . they flood in and are super overwhelming . <end>

title: <start> question male suicide rising <end>
response: <start> i am not sure we will ever know a why but only be able to find correlations between subjects . i personally feel from my anecdotal experience that even though some of the stigma has been reduced regarding men coming forward about their emotions , there is also less grey area and more extreme opinions being spread across the media . . . so there are a lot of people who say yes , absolutely men should come forward if they are feeling depressed and have issues to work through and a lot of people saying absolutely not , why in the world can not he just buck up and deal with it and not many people in between . therefore , if someone is seeking therapy , they might be returning to a stigmatizing social group or home life . or , they come from a stigmatizing or radicalized social group and do not try to seek help . the men i have seen who make the most progress in therapy also have an incredible support group outside of their counselor or therapy group , and those who struggle tend to return to their poor habits or unhealthy environments when they leave counseling and feel as though they are not able to find healthier relationships . another important consideration is the methods men and women tend to use to complete suicide . men tend to use more lethal methods gun wounds , hanging , jumping and women tend to use less lethal methods cutting , pills . the generally accepted statistics regarding suicide in the us states that x as many men complete suicide and x as many women attempt suicide . so there are generally the same amount of individuals who have a desire to contemplate suicide but the running theory is that men actually complete more frequently is due to the severity of their attempts . <end>

response: <start> i appreciate what you have written here . the stats regarding suicide attempts in your last paragraph are not news to me , but should be a part of this thread nonetheless . you are right about the extreme opinions in the media , and there being little in between . here in australia we do not get much of the buck up and deal with it stuff anymore . . . instead every media personality spouts the same thing regarding men need to open up more . if that is all that men need to be doing , then our suicide rate here should be getting better surely , even if just a tiny bit because men are opening up more . slowly , yes , but we definitely have more men opening up more now than we used to . we have a long way to go , but today we have so much more encouragement than we used to regarding mental health treatment , yet the rate of suicide is getting worse . x b i am wondering if there is any correlation between the the rise of male suicide and the changing definition of what it means to be masculine a man . <end>

title: <start> what do you consider trauma <end>
response: <start> to have something diagnosable as ptsd , the requirements are threats to life or bodily injury , to yourself , someone you know or witnessing it happening to someone else . now , this is up for interpretation as younger children may perceive threats to life differently . such as , a small child losing a caregiver could be considered life threatening , as a small child can not take care of themselves . but therapists often talk about big t trauma and little t trauma . big t , are the physical risks , abuse , sexual assault , etc . little t are the emotionally pains . this article actually does a pretty good job talking about them link http www . google . com amp s www . psychologytoday . com us blog trauma and hope different types trauma small t versus large t famp i personally use a trauma informed perspective and always consider trauma first . many times if trauma has occurred , it can explain symptoms . trauma can also mimic many disorders , and looks different in everyone . many times i see trauma symptoms in relationships where there is emotional abuse neglect . trauma is really in the eye of the experiencer . what is your perspective . how hurtful was it , how damaging , did it change the way you see yourself or the world . those can tell a lot . if your perspective of yourself , others or the world has changed , it is likely that trauma has occurred . the good news , trauma can be healed but it must be processed and worked through . it does not heal magically on its own with time . time can make it better , but the triggers will remain . <end>

response: <start> sweetie , take all the proof you have to the police in order to see if you can get a restraining order against her . see if you can get your parents help . you do not have to give them all the details , just tell them that this girl has mental issues , and is trying to make your life hell . changing your number is a good idea . document all calls from random numbers that you receive , and ask your friends to do the same . where you live , is a therapist covered by insurance please visit one , and ask them how you could protect yourself if someone threatens to report you to the police as suicidal . call the police too , and ask their advice . in a lot of places , you could be forced to be under psychiatric supervision for two days , if they suspect you are suicidal , so it is a big deal , but you can still protect yourself against it by letting the police know beforehand . it appears that she is not a minor anymore , so the legal repercussions for her would be much much worse than if she was a minor . actually , i think you might be able to get her to quit bothering you if you document all proof and send it to her , letting her know that you will take it all to the authorities if she ever bothers you , your friends or loved ones again . if you are in the us , google if your state is a one party consent state . if it is , you can record phone conversations with her him whatever without their consent , and it can be used in court against them . if not , try to have as many conversations as you can through texts , and they can be used as evidence against her . lastly , this is going to be the hardest , please try not to judge yourself for things that you allowed to happen . i have been in similar situations , and letting go of that self judgement is the single hardest thing i have ever done , and it is also the biggest step toward healing and moving forward . good luck and lots of love . <end>

title: <start> have you ever been emotionally overwhelmed or attached to one of your patients and if so , how did you ease the counter transference <end>
response: <start> this happened to me a few weeks ago . my client shared something that i related to and i did become emotionally overwhelmed , however was able to keep it in check until after our session had concluded . i had to look at the part of me that was reacting so much to what my client had told me and see why it had affected me so . in this case , loneliness was the emotion and i had to look at when i had felt that lonely recently and process that on my own . if our client impacts us that much in a session and we notice it , chances are our clients notice it as well . moving forward , giving its used with the right intent and purpose , i believe using self disclosure to let your client know how much something they may have said has impacted you would be appropriate . given you have processed that and looked into that outside of session first . <end>

title: <start> i am not sure what is wrong with me anymore <end>
response: <start> i would recommend setting an alarm on your phone to make sure you are taking your medication regularly , this can drastically reduce your symptoms . i know you mentioned that when you took your medication consistently for months , your episodes reduced , so that is a good sign that your medication is helping your symptoms . another good thing to add to your daily routine is moments of mindfulness . you can coordinate this with the time you take your medication as well let your husband or whoever else might interrupt know that you are going to take minutes that need to be uninterrupted . you can sit in a comfortable position , put on some music without words , close your eyes , and focus on how your body feels . focus on the way your bottom feels on the surface your sitting on , your feet or legs on the floor , the weight of your arms , or the weight of your head on your neck . if your mind wanders to the dishes or any concerns , acknowledge the thought but refocus on your senses . i know it sounds kind of hippy but it really helps to connect your brain with your body and you can use those skills over time to calm your mind when you have a feeling of becoming overwhelmed . so when you see those dishes piling up and you start to become anxious , bring yourself back into the present moment and refocus on your body for a moment before deciding how you want to handle the situation . i hope this is helpful if you would like to start going to therapy , there are some therapists who will do therapy out of pocket or offer sliding scale payments which are based on your income . <end>

title: <start> was i sexually abused <end>
response: <start> it is kind of hard for people to wrap their heads around the idea that a child can abuse another child , especially when the children in question are siblings . technically speaking , yes , your sister was sexually abusing you . whether or not you should see it that way is another story . some people process situations like yours as experimentation , weird , but not abuse , or gray area , or something else without a negative connotation . and if you would prefer to see it that way , good for you . but if that type of perspective is not working for you , then you can define it as abuse by looking at the power dynamics of the situation . <end>

response: <start> not sure this helps , but i had a difficult childhood . my memories never matched what i would consider abuse . turns out though , it does not matter what it was . abuse neglect bullying what matters is that without asking my childhood body and brain stored it as trauma and i developed beliefs about myself from these difficult events . it is been hard and slow to accept that i have trauma that has left me depressed and anxious as an adult . but gosh , once i started to accept that it was trauma still unsure about if it was abuse and learn about trauma , wow everything makes much more sense . i actually feel better knowing what i am experiencing has a name trauma , it is unfortunately common see this sub and there are therapies available to heal from it . i am working with an emir therapist to process certain things from childhood . i also hope to do mdma sometime soon . not every situation fits into a neat category here like so much of life and that is okay healing can happen regardless of your situation . chin up , friend , i get it . <end>

title: <start> older adult with possible eating disorder <end>
response: <start> sorry to answer your question evasively , but this seems to be more about you wanting your mom in treatment than about what the diagnosis would be also , we can not responsibly diagnose someone without meeting them . you are clearly concerned for her . it seems that perhaps other family members are too . i suggest having a conversation with your mother that focuses on i statements . stick to your perspective and what you see . something like , i would like you to get help for an eating disorder , mom . i think it is obvious that you are under weight , and i feel like this is a risk to your well being if you do not get help . i love you and i will respect whatever your decision is , but i feel awful when i see you behave in xyz fashion . if you do not seek treatment , then i will do zy to protect myself and my feelings . the treatment resources for eating disorders are generally the same regardless of age , as far as i know it is not an area i spend a lot of time on . despite the image that eating disorders are a teenager s problem , they can be diagnosed at a variety of ages , so your mom probably would not be the only year old at a treatment facility or support group this would be something you could ask about with the people running programs in your area as i am just guessing . <end>

title: <start> have you ever cured a patient of anxiety or depression <end>
response: <start> that is . . . extremely hard to say . like , i had someone recently who had some family strife and it was causing her to meet criteria for generalized anxiety disorder , so we addressed some underlying communication and boundary issues , and she was more or less symptom free by the end of therapy . so , cured i honestly do not know . <end>

response: <start> i am not a therapist , but i can speak from personal experience . i am the same way . i had one abusive marriage and one mutual convenience marriage he was dying and wanted someone to care for him and make sure his parent did not get anything of his i am now in a relationship with a man that has the same feelings as me . we are best friends , we both know that love is a chemical response to attraction and whilst we are attracted to each other we do not always get that little rush of chemical responses . we do not say i love you every day , but we both know that we put each other first . we are both in our s . you are right now , there is no rush to find the one which does not actually there is one single person , it could be multiple people take your time , live , break a few hearts honorably which just means the way you are doing right now , being upfront about not being emotionally available for a relationship eventually you will find what you want and that person or persons will accept you as you are . <end>

title: <start> how to grieve and get over guilt that it was not me instead <end>
response: <start> i am sorry about your loss . i know it might be hard to see right now , but people around you are not going to be happy if you are dead . . and if i can be blunt . . just like you are not happy with your cousin dead . this sounds like what is called complicated grief and sounds like it had a traumatic impact on you . an ongoing therapist or counsellor can help . if you live in canada or the us you can call for referrals , or ask your family doctor . you can also call a crisis line and ask for a referral . all live is valuable and just because you have not done what you would like to yet , does not mean you can not in the future . <end>

title: <start> i m have been a push over in every romantic relationship i have ever been in <end>
response: <start> i am of the opinion that the why is not necessarily something a therapist can answer and i also believe the why is not too important . what is more important is how you will move on from your learned experiences . you have described three instances that have had a big impact on you and are still impacting you it is normal to grieve those losses , be upset , and feel like there is something you could have done most people do that after break ups . it does seem like you are ruminating on this quite a bit , especially with how you mentioned seeing social media activity from your exes that made you uncomfortable . my suggestion for this is to disengage with exes on social media delete , block , whatever you are comfortable doing to no longer see their feed . resist the urge to check in on them . remember that they have chosen to not be a part of your romantic life anymore , and honor that by not participating in it in your own time whether they know about you being a participant or not . you said you forget about yourself , when you are in a relationship now that you are not in a relationship , it is the perfect time to remember yourself and meditating , working out , and performing your best at work are all excellent ways to remember your talents and develop your personhood . why even bother why not bother i know you are feeling apathetic about wellness but start small . would it hurt to take minutes a day to meditate , or minutes to work out i am of the belief that working on yourself and having a strong identity would help prevent that feeling of your personhood getting swept away when getting into a relationship . what are the boundaries in your other relationships like working on those boundaries can be useful practice for romantic relationships . i would encourage you to tell someone no once a day . it does not matter what you are saying no to , it could be something very small or insignificant that you could say yes . i will admit that i need to practice saying no sometimes because it reminds me that i have the ability to do it . it is important to be comfortable saying no to little things because then it will be easier saying no when you feel like a boundary is being violated . i hope this gives some useful insight <end>

response: <start> hi x b thank you for your answer . when i think about my boundaries in regular life , i feel i am quite comfortable with saying no . with setting boundaries . i trust that the people i reject will stay and if not that i will be able to quickly reciprocate and make everything alright . x b i believe that it is specifically in romantic relationships where i become a proper pleaser . x b as long as the dynamic is alright , i am fine as well . but i am horrible at prioritizing other things myself included once i am with someone . this is when my meditation goes out the window , working out gets done sometimes , time spent with friends is kept to a minimal . this is regardless of if the relationship is going great or is hanging on by a thread . x b at the sight of some form of disinterest from the potential or already established partner , i try my best to please , i get clingy . in the end i like to think of it as trying my best , but i guess in reality i have just done myself a huge disfavor . x b i will of course take my time now to try and heal myself . but i just can not help but to think that i have done this before . and that it is not until i figure out why i am like this , and dealing with it properly that i will ever prioritize myself and my own well being properly once in a romantic relationship . <end>

title: <start> hi x b thank you for your answer . when i think about my boundaries in regular life , i feel i am quite comfortable with saying no . with setting boundaries . i trust that the people i reject will stay and if not that i will be able to quickly reciprocate and make everything alright . x b i believe that it is specifically in romantic relationships where i become a proper pleaser . x b as long as the dynamic is alright , i am fine as well . but i am horrible at prioritizing other things myself included once i am with someone . this is when my meditation goes out the window , working out gets done sometimes , time spent with friends is kept to a minimal . this is regardless of if the relationship is going great or is hanging on by a thread . x b at the sight of some form of disinterest from the potential or already established partner , i try my best to please , i get clingy . in the end i like to think of it as trying my best , but i guess in reality i have just done myself a huge disfavor . x b i will of course take my time now to try and heal myself . but i just can not help but to think that i have done this before . and that it is not until i figure out why i am like this , and dealing with it properly that i will ever prioritize myself and my own well being properly once in a romantic relationship . <end>
response: <start> it is good to hear you have good boundaries in other areas of your life that means you have a good gauge for who you feel you can trust with rejection . that might be a good thing for you to consider when you do start seeing someone romantically when you feel your potential romantic partner is crossing a boundary or you should say no , ask yourself if this were friend asking this , would i say no if you would say no to anyone else , say no to them . you have to learn their level of rejection perception and it is not fair for you to assume your partner can not handle rejection and as you have learned , it only reinforces negative behaviors . you can also reflect on the times you said yes when you should have said no and imagine how you could have said no not as an effort to rekindle anything , but as a practice for when you need to say no to a new partner . having a firm schedule is a good way to make sure you are not becoming too clingy or being a people pleaser as well . if you decide to workout from pm on mondays , wednesdays , and thursdays , or you make a plan with a friend , commit to it . if a non emergency comes up and your partner wants to hang out i have to go to the gym , but i can hang out other time . major life events might deviate this schedule , but setting the schedule before you enter a potential partnership and holding true to it through courting and dating is a good way to establish to your partner your boundaries and ensure you have time to remember the things that are important to you . if your potential partner wigs out over this , red flag alert . it can also be helpful to talk to friends about it . let me give you a hypothetical , i hope it is not too obtuse or abstract you decide to meet up for dinner and drinks with a friend you have not seen in a month . your partner texts to hang out instead but you tell them i have plans with jimmy , but i am free tomorrow at partner replies saying , that is really selfish of you , i really just want to spend time with you and you are not here for me , but does not have a legitimate reason no death in the family , they are not ill , etc for you choosing to hang out with partner over your friend who you have had plans with for weeks . you choose to hang out with your friend because you promised yourself you would not cancel your plans . at dinner , you mention that your partner got upset when you chose to hang out with jimmy instead of partner . how does jimmy react he may say , what a load of horseshit , throwaways , partner has no reason to be upset , we have had these plans for weeks then you have some confirmation that this is a red flag alert and can open the conversation with your partner about how their behavior crossed a boundary for you . you could always go to some psychoanalyst and learn that when you were a child you saw your parents do x , y , and z and that is why you are having problems with boundaries in romantic relationships , but is that knowledge going to do anything for you it may be helpful to see a therapist regardless i think everyone benefits from therapy , even when people use it as a preventative measure but try not to get stuck on the why but focus on the how and what how can i improve boundary setting in romantic relationships and what can i do differently next time <end>

response: <start> i have to say that your responses are really insightful , thank you x b i might add that in this last relationship . to begin with , i was not the one dealing with unacceptable behaviour . i was the one acting out a little bit over small stuff , because i was afraid that it was a sign of her backing off . but as the relationship grew more complicated , i was the one that was left accepting a situation that was just bad for me . x b i had a similar realization to the one i have had now with my second relationship that ended . i realized that i really had to love myself , as corny as it sounds , in order to set these boundaries . in order to prioritize myself when so that i am never too clingy or needy , but also so that when a situation occurs when i need to put my foot down , it will come natural to me . x b but i guess something happened a long the way . this was more than a year ago . i am guessing that it might have to do with me using casual partners , tinder and dating in general as a way of coping with being single . i have always heard people say get a rebound go on and date casually , basically sleep around until you are sick of it . i would not say that i was destructive in any way , but maybe it altered my focus a little too much . x b it makes sense that maybe i was just using something other than a relationship in order to deal with whatever insecurities and esteem issues that i was experiencing . x b do you have any idea of what type of practical activities i could engage in in order to help cultivate a healthier relationship towards myself <end>

title: <start> i have to say that your responses are really insightful , thank you x b i might add that in this last relationship . to begin with , i was not the one dealing with unacceptable behaviour . i was the one acting out a little bit over small stuff , because i was afraid that it was a sign of her backing off . but as the relationship grew more complicated , i was the one that was left accepting a situation that was just bad for me . x b i had a similar realization to the one i have had now with my second relationship that ended . i realized that i really had to love myself , as corny as it sounds , in order to set these boundaries . in order to prioritize myself when so that i am never too clingy or needy , but also so that when a situation occurs when i need to put my foot down , it will come natural to me . x b but i guess something happened a long the way . this was more than a year ago . i am guessing that it might have to do with me using casual partners , tinder and dating in general as a way of coping with being single . i have always heard people say get a rebound go on and date casually , basically sleep around until you are sick of it . i would not say that i was destructive in any way , but maybe it altered my focus a little too much . x b it makes sense that maybe i was just using something other than a relationship in order to deal with whatever insecurities and esteem issues that i was experiencing . x b do you have any idea of what type of practical activities i could engage in in order to help cultivate a healthier relationship towards myself <end>
response: <start> as far as practical activities to better your self esteem . . . here s some that i like for every one negative thing you think about yourself , think of more that you like . anything from waking up in the morning and looking in the mirror and think wow , the bags under my eyes are terrible today , to feeling down about your performance at work . combat every negative thought about yourself with good thoughts . if you can not shake the negative thought , think about if it is something you are able to change . you mentioned you go to the gym , so if it is a body image concern , commit to going more frequently or looking up healthy workout and diet plans . if you have the money , see a nutritionist or trainer to tailor a workout and diet plan that fits your goals . take some time every day to be mindful . that could be meditation , or even just admiring nature . do not time yourself , and set an alarm if you have something to do at a particular time so you do not get lost in the moment . enjoying life and the people and things around me has greatly increased my own quality of life . do you have any hobbies i can not recall at the moment , but there is a sub for inexpensive free hobbies . you can always try something new , of course being aware that you are not going to be great right away , but it can feel good to cultivate a skill . <end>

title: <start> overcoming a lifetime of fear <end>
response: <start> he hello are you me from the past the whole thing , everything you wrote . sounds like your dad gives off angry energy . his energy is not yours . find your own center and rest peacefully there . practice all the time , but the best times to practice are when he is directing his energy toward you . this is when your knee jerk reaction is to grab ahold of his negative energy , make it your own and mirror it back to him . stop being a mirror for him . reacting in kind to his energy only makes that energy stronger , in him , in you , in anyone else present . so an outburst from you makes it worse for your wellbeing , and everyone else s involved . if he approaches you with anger , respond with kindness , always . how start by learning to see your anger , and his , when it is welling up inside you . watch it , but do not act or speak out because of it . just let it be , it will pass . over time , when you continue to respond with calm kindness , he will eventually start interacting with you differently . you can and should stand up for yourself , but not defensively , just calmly , kindly , matter of fatly . worked for me , took about a year , now me and pops get along like peanut butter jelly . you can too . best of luck friend <end>

response: <start> i do understand what you are saying , but my current therapist is that sort of person . i like him a lot he is kind and understanding and i have never felt unsafe when telling him everything , even the stuff he does not understand . but for me and my problems , talking . . . . . is not enough and i do not think it will change at all . he does not have the knowledge to help me through my ptsd symptoms . he does not understand my did and dissociation . he gets my autism , but my problems are all combined with each other when i vent , so in the end all i do is dump a fuck ton because there is so much going on inside me and i come out of it with nothing figured out . there is little things he is helped with for sure , it is not like he is done nothing for me . but they are tiny things , generally again centered on autism while all the other boatload of problems regarding my other disorders and symptoms are left untouched . so , i do get what you are saying here as i have had bad therapists . and i am thankful to have my current one who i can at least stick with for now . but i am the long term , this is not going to get me anywhere i do not think . edit adding , i a good therapist is one you get along with and connect , no doubt . but my disorders are complex and all of them put together is an even bigger mess . did is gravely misunderstood . if the therapist does not understand any of what i am throwing at them , their methods and ways of helping me are useless . my current therapist is great in that he is nice and has helped a little bit . but in the end his knowledge is not diverse enough and the therapy he provides does not get me anywhere with the two other disorders greatly affecting my life <end>

title: <start> how to overcome transference <end>
response: <start> hopefully your therapist is trained and experienced enough to explore with you the meaning of this transference . you can also help yourself work through the transference by recognizing so much of it is driven by the supportive nature of the therapeutic relationship with no demands being placed upon you to do anything to support this relationship . but recognize that the relationship is profoundly one sided . a friendship is not one sided . a friendship with your former therapist , if such a thing was ethically possible , would be very different from your therapeutic relationship . it would naturally demand support and accommodation by you towards your former therapist as any friendship would demand . in such a friendship you would have a completely different experience of your therapist . in fact you might discover that you do not even like your therapist as a friend <end>

title: <start> how to be more motivated amp better at decision making <end>
response: <start> it sounds like a lot of different issues have snowballed and blended into a tangled mess of generally feeling unhappy . from what you have said , you did not get to spend a lot of time as a child adolescent getting to know who you are . you have always been working and taking on very grown up roles . i am also hearing a lot of internalized pressure . it sounds as though you believe every time you make it over the next hurdle you will find happiness . it does not sound like you have a balanced life . think of your life like slices of a pie , with equal amounts of energy going to each slice . you need slices for work , friendship , love , spirituality , hobbies . spend some time getting to know who you are outside of work and academics . figure out what is fun to you . start talking back to these negative voices in your head . this is where therapy can truly help . it may also help in addressing some of the childhood experiences that are likely the root of those negative messages . do better with self care , including adding some pleasure in your life . good luck to you <end>

title: <start> is this a problem or is everyone just different <end>
response: <start> anger is considered a secondary emotion . like , no one is ever just angry , they are hurt and angry , or frustrated and angry , or scared and angry , etc , etc . people , sometimes especially men depending on their parents , get the message that anger is normal expected but other emotions are not , so a lot of emotions get absorbed into and covered with anger . i sort of agree with the other poster who said if it is not causing problems , it is not a problem , but i also know that men who are able to articulate a wider range of emotions typically have more satisfying relationships . it sounds like you have curiosity about it , and asking an actual therapist about it could give you a better idea of what is going on for you with it . <end>

title: <start> i want to bang my therapist <end>
response: <start> yes , talk about them to the extent that you can . it is understandably awkward and uncomfortable . it will also probably feel like an elephant in the room and will not go away until you acknowledge it . as you have read , it is a normal and common response to therapy . if your therapist felt the need to refer you elsewhere over this , then she is not a good therapist . upping your frequency is something to discuss , though if you feel you have more material you need to start addressing which sounds like it could be the case , then seeing her more often would make sense . if you are unsure how to start talking about it , you could always use hypotheticals what would you do if a client said x or a bit of preparation there is something on my mind that i would like to talk about but i am concerned about your response . both of these might give you a little information about how she could handle it and then you have more knowledge about how you would feel most comfortable proceeding . <end>

title: <start> therapist shouting stuff during one session , suggests crazy things , inpatient , etc . <end>
response: <start> i would move on and find someone else . this therapist sounds a little too paranoid . suicidal ideology admissions by a client can be tough to deal with i would imagine , but the last thing you need is someone yelling at you if you have those kinds of thoughts . i admitted to my therapist that i was suicidal , and even details about what i would do . she saw this as a brave admission and a reach out for help . it was after the fact , and i did not obviously go through with it . she did , in a very calm way , ensure that i had no current plans of self harm and was very supportive and compassionate . i would suggest you take the time to interview your next therapist before committing to work with them . all them how they handle these kinds of things and tell them about this experience and how it made you feel . you deserve someone who you can be real with , even if it is stuff like this without getting the shit scared out of you for it . <end>

title: <start> what are my options <end>
response: <start> the therapist may not be comfortable going forward with couples therapy if your husband himself needs more attention specifically to his symptoms or if he feels it is out of his competence but definitely ask the therapist and he should honestly let you know why . as to your question about specific therapies , cognitive behavioral therapy known as cut is one of the most evidence based and effective forms of therapy used for ptsd i would consider looking for a therapist who specializes in cut . rational emotive behavioral therapy rest has shown good outcomes with ptsd but it can be intense . another good thing to remember is that a person has to be ready and willing to change his behavior . <end>

response: <start> this sounds like it is been a really good coping mechanism for you , especially when falling asleep like you said it is not hurting or impeding on your life . . . so why would it be a problem if you are worried about it interfering with your life when you day dream meaning during the day and that it might affect your interpersonal relationships , there are lots of other mindfulness exercises that could be helpful to you to swap out with your day dreaming . some that i particularly like are if my dog starts scratching himself i count how many times he kicks his leg then list as many things or people that i am grateful for make shapes out of patterns in ceilings y know those popcorn ceilings or the ones with all the little dots breathing exercises i like breathing in for seconds , and out for seconds if i am sitting down and start to feel my mind wander , i will press my feet harder on the ground and try to concentrate on the soles of my feet for seconds again , there are lots if these exercises , and i would recommend going to a book store and flipping through some self help mindfulness books with exercises , and picking out one that resonates with you <end>

response: <start> schizophrenia is not the only disorder that causes hallucinations . many diagnoses have a qualifier called with psychotic features and while it sounds scary , all psychotic means is that there are hallucinations or delusions of some sort present . if you previously were diagnosed with an anxiety disorder and dissociated , it is possible that this is a new manifestation . something to keep in mind is if this is distressing to you , or causing life impairments . it sounds like it is increasing over time , so it might be a good idea to talk to a therapist or psychiatrist or both . it may be the stress is too much , and you need some new ways to cope . <end>

title: <start> short and easy question <end>
response: <start> since i have very little information on you specifically , i will speak generally . yes , people who have a history of attachment issues and trauma can be avoidant of closeness to others for a variety of reasons . it can be painful , fear of getting close to someone who will abandon you or lack of trust . avoidance is a main feature of trauma , and avoidant is one of the insecure attachment styles . basically , i am going to keep you at arms length because it makes me feel safer if you get close to me that will be uncomfortable scary if this is something you are interested in learning more about , there is a wonderful book called attached by amir levyne <end>

title: <start> do you think some people are will never live enjoyable lives <end>
response: <start> probably not a popular answer , but yes . why because i think some people do not have the foresight to find happiness in difficult times and others because it is genetically improbable ie dysthymia . i think that happiness is a choice . i have seen people who have had some serious trauma and unfortunate events happen that still find their happiness . it is definitely frustrating for me , wanting to provide relief . i keep seeing people and hold on hope that one day something in them might change . <end>

title: <start> becoming an adult sucks . what should i do <end>
response: <start> well first of all , your great grandparents are saints for raising you . at that point in life , they had earned some rest so god bless them for raising a child for that you should be eternally thankful . imo your great grandmother has earned a free pass for pretty much anything she wants low , including talking about whoever she wants . the secret to happiness comes from within , not from the outside . you will not find it in your friends , or your job , or your girlfriends . in today s society , we are conditioned to believe we will be happy once we achieve certain milestones . for example once i graduate , then life starts , or once i get this job , or promotion , then i will be happy or once i buy my first house , than i can finally be happy , or once i get a of i love , then i will be happy . the list goes on and on and is literally infinite , as is our list of wants . if you attach your happiness to things or people you will inevitably be let down because you will always want more . focus on yourself , learn to be happy in the moment itself . create healthy habits and practice self care exercise , eat well , and sleep well . you are , at the very beginning of your life you have the whole world in your hand , so what are you going to do with it take it from a guy who is , and has children . do not waste your s focusing on what you do not have . use it to create the life you want , and find happiness in every moment . happiness is not the destination , but your means of travel . <end>

title: <start> what should i expect from sex therapy as a survivor of sexual abuse assault <end>
response: <start> it is understandable to feel nervous . it sounds like you have been through so much and kudos to you for continuing to choose healing , even when doing so has been incredibly difficult . i think above all else , you should expect collaboration between yourself and the clinician . the therapist should always provide you with options that support your personal agency , healing , and goals . agree sensate focusing is likely to be introduced and discussed in session . also likely is that homework will be assigned to you and partner to practice touch both independently you to yourself , for example , with possibly recording what areas feel nice , calming , safe and as a couple as treatment progresses goals allow . the clinician may also suggest creating a body map which is more or less what it sounds like a visual tool , using a color coordinated ratings , to understand where trauma resides in your body and where feels nice less nice never okay to be touched . it is possible the clinician will also utilize mindfulness techniques which it sounds like you may already been familiar with due to debt skills to support emotional regulation and help train the brain to process fear , etc . differently . regardless , it sounds like you have already done a lot of strong work . it is clear self awareness , growth , and recovery are important to you . a good therapist will help you in ways unique to your specific case and give you lots of options , . best of luck to you . i think you are very brave . <end>

response: <start> thank you , that is so incredibly kind of you to say . i have always been a very big believer in helpfulness of therapy and working through traumas . i am not familiar with what sensate focusing is , so i have made that to be some research homework for myself . it is nice to know that my partner will be included in the process , he is very big on being informed of healing strategies and what i am going through so he will be really happy to know that and i will feel much safer with him there . that is a really interesting concept , i had not even heard or thought of that and even now i can kind of tell where my trauma sits in my body . do you eventually work through all the negative spots and heal the trauma or is it just to be informed of what is off limits for good that is great , i did weeks of debt and found it really challenging but super helpful so it would be really good to utilise that in the treatment and help retrain my brain . those are honestly my main priorities in life and i have been working on really refining those areas as much as i can at a healthy pace for the past few years and it is been making a world of difference . i hope my therapist i eventually am paired with is as informative and helpful as you are . thank you so much for your guidance , advice and lovely words , i really truly appreciate it and i hope the sun shines down on you forever <end>

title: <start> friend is an alcoholic and depressed . what should i do <end>
response: <start> go to a friend s and family smart recovery meeting online in person , or al anon steps for friends family . i am not a therapist but have six years sober . i had friends reach out to family , my school , etc and honestly it was all useless until i was able to understand the consequences in my own way . for me this turned out to be jail , twice . the important thing is to set boundaries to keep yourself safe and really take an honest look at yourself to see if you are enabling him on any way . if so , cut that off as soon as you can . i hope your friend can get help soon and i hope you check out one or both of those meetings for yourself . <end>

title: <start> how to ask my dad about molestation and move on ink if these feelings are valid . any input is appreciated . . <end>
response: <start> so sorry this has you in such a quandary . from everything you describe it seems pretty certain that you were sexually abused . if a client asked me the question you are asking i would ask them what would their dad s admission of guilt resolve for them i ask this because your dad may not be forth coming at all regarding this . very few abusers admit to their behavior in any authentic manner . they usually deny , dismiss it or grossly minimize it . you do not want the resolution of this abuse to depend upon your dad being forthcoming because he most likely will not be . you do not want to be vulnerable to further psychological abuse by depending upon him to tell you the truth . you could ask your dad this question but do not depend upon his answer to resolve anything about what occurred . good luck with all of this . <end>

title: <start> conflict of interest <end>
response: <start> if the person doing providing your therapy is not a licensed therapist , licensed by your state province country , they are not really held to any ethical standards and can do anything they want . they are not required to disclose anything to you or even really keep what you say confidential . if they are a therapist licensed by your state licensing board , they are not able to do this kind of thing as they are held to a code of ethics and are subject to certain laws regarding confidentiality and dual relationships . in most cases , therapists will not see two members of the same family . the only exception is if you live in an area where it would be an undue burden for them to find another therapist say the only other therapist that takes their insurance is or more miles away . in cases where a client does see a family member , they are never allowed to disclose information about past clients or that they even know who they are without written consent . my guess is that your sister mother s therapist never even said that to your mother and she made it up . if your therapist is aware ahead of time that your mother may try to do this and they recognize her name , if they are ethical , and also licensed held to an ethical code they will not see her and will refer her to someone else . if by chance they started seeing her and only found out later , they would most likely decide to drop her as they took her after you unless you were about done with therapy , but once again , only if they are a licensed therapist . <end>

title: <start> what do i even search for when looking for help <end>
response: <start> hi there psychiatrists are medical doctors and write prescriptions . in the states , they more often will also do counselling than they do in canada . google relationship counsellor in x where you live or counselling in x psychologists , social workers , psychotherapists , marriage and family counsellors , all provide counselling . they are simply trained and educated in different ways . it can be important to differentiate , but often it is not important to differentiate . i would start with individual counselling with a counsellor who also has some experience in relationships . go into your first sessions telling them that you are unsure whether you should be seeing them individually or as part of a couple and ask them to assess and make a recommendation based on that . <end>

response: <start> does not sound like anything is wrong with you . from what you are saying , it sounds like your mother failed to nurture you in ways that develop attachment bonds , and now you do not feel attached to her . it tracks pretty logically . you also feel resentment for her when she attempts to manipulate your emotions , and you close yourself off because you sense that she is not being authentic with you . it is a sign of good boundaries . it sounds like you feel guilt over the idea of not being there for your mother , but she has not done her part to earn that sacred relationship with you . it is only natural . and she is responsible for her own happiness . sounds like you have taken responsibility for yours . <end>

title: <start> help <end>
response: <start> not a therapist , but here s my uneducated opinion without knowing the type of abuse or who you as a person . this will probably be bad advise because i am not educated and i do not know the situation . x b if i was you , i probably have already learned how to partition your personalities . keeping the hurt and fear away from the public and only showing the happy and carefree . x b use that . when you are feeling like less than worth existing , use it to treat yourself to an experience that you think someone you may think is better than you . masquerade as an amazing person with an interesting life . use your ability to create happiness and portray joy to show yourself what it looks like . instead of using it to perform for others , perform only for yourself . if you do not feel the motivation to perform or you feel that you are not worthy of the performance . . then practice for the big show . practice for when you feel like you are worth it . practice it until you are a professional at being happy and carefree . x b i would first try getting a gourmet meal at a star fine dining restaurant . order the special . let yourself enjoy it . do not let others looks discourage yourself . you are there to show yourself that you are the strong and powerful person that is able to eat alone in public and you are not concerning yourself about a strangers opinion . i would maybe try making a sand castle , if you are near a beach , or a mud castle if you are near the forest . this would help me have a fun and interesting project that is just for me . knowing it will just be washed away by the next high tide or heavy rain . i can do anything i want and not worry about it being judged . i would make a castle that i would love to picture how it would be used by a society . i would image i am the royalty , or member of the court , or a servant . . . any of them that would be fine , i would be chronically the scandals and secrets and odd interactions because i am the only one above all of them and i am able to view their network of whispers in their fullness . i would try to say hello to a stranger , maybe a smile . especially an older person that may be at the end of a long day or a person that i pass in the store . not for anything but knowing that people tend to smile back or get a moment of subconscious joy when someone smiles or says hi to them . i would know that i am bringing positivity to others just by catching their attention with a smile , a hi , or a thank you . that is pretty much just existing . by just existing i am bringing joy to others . acknowledge that , keep it close to your heart , let yourself believe it . volunteer at a pet shelter . wash a dog , walk a dog , let the dogs know you will be back to give them a good scratch . learn how you can volunteer with training them or posting media online or offline to help them get adopted . x b lastly , but should really be first , consult a therapist professional . x b i hope this helps and or inspires something helpful in you <end>

response: <start> i am not a therapist yet , but i can answer some of your questions . where are you located state country etc . florida , usa . about how much do you make per year i am an unpaid intern right now , but the treatment center that i am interning at starts their therapists at , a year . . what was your major in college and what is your highest level of education i am almost finished with my master s in clinical mental health counseling . my bachelor s degree is in psychology . once i am finished i will be able to become a registered intern and i can start getting paid . i will be under supervision for years and have to have , hours before i can become licensed in florida . . what type of therapist are you and what are you specialized in i am recently emir trained , but i use a variety of therapy techniques . . do you work with a specific age group the treatment center i intern at is specifically for adolescent girls and i really love working with this population . . about how many clients do you work with right now as an intern i am working with clients who i see once a week . the therapists that i work with typically have a caseload of and they have to see them all twice a week and run groups a week . they also have to communicate with all the caseworkers and have a weekly treatment team that lasts about hours . . most importantly , do you enjoy your job it definitely has its ups and downs , but i really love what i do . <end>

title: <start> should i see a different therapist <end>
response: <start> therapist here . we are legally bound to report any instance of suspected potential child abuse or neglect . her delivery was off and she could have brought up the issue about her legal obligation to report such things in a very different way . it would have been better if she helped you through the crisis first , then discussed the cps reporting afterwards . she can not be validating towards actions that are unhealthy for you and your children , but she should been validating that you were in distress and your feelings , so i would not say this is a case of tough love in that sense . <end>

title: <start> this is an excellent response . kids are often used as pawns , but know that if you start going to extreme legal means , you will also be using him as a pawn . he misses her , he is telling you that . mom is not able to give him the love he needs from her , and you can not change that . give him instead what you can . be the safe loving mother she can not be , and know that he will always wish he had more from her . therapy can help him make meaning of his experiences . she likely loves him as best she can , and as long as she is good enough as protective services define a parent that can keep their children , children who are free from harm and abuse then her best is going to have to be enough . <end>
response: <start> this . having gone through this an a similar situation , you need to learn to let go after a while . an emotionally abusive mother is just that , and while it is absolutely heartbreaking to have to witness , there really is not much that you can do . you can not fix the other parent , and chances are you can not fix the situation because it is very , very hard to prove . the mother is unavailable because the child is her source of validation . is it awful yes . can you prove it doubtful . will the child be okay probably . i cannot stress enough that the most important thing you can do is learn to let go . do not fixate . you cannot change the circumstances he is in there . trust me . but you can show him real love , you can show him stability , you can show him happiness . my best advice having been in your shoes is for dad to be the best damned dad he can be , and you to be the best stereom you can be . you will not , can not and should not replace mom . but you can be an ally , you can be a friend , you can be a positive maternal figure . and in the end , it will act as a balance to the less than perfect situation he has there . stay out of it . do not mention his mom . just love and support him in those moments . you can be frustrated and upset when you see this happen , which you will be because you love this child . but that is your burden , and it needs to stay with you . just focus on yourself , your home , and the life you build with him when he is there . accept what you can not fix and trust what you can give . <end>

title: <start> eating disorders what are they , and do i have one <end>
response: <start> hi there , i am years old and i did not realize i have been living with an eating disorder until my sophomore year of high school . i remember changing in the girls locker room and reading a poster about the signs of someone having an eating disorder . it really really made me panic . three years later , i somewhat still have an eating disorder . i have all of thoughts and feelings you feel with food as well . my best advice would be to get help . if you do not want to go that far though since you might not want your parents knowing , understand that is food is something our bodies need . in order to be healthy and live our crazy active lives we need to have food . start looking at food as a good thing . i understand that you feel pressured to look as good as the other guys in your grade but remember , you can still have a super nice body and eat meals a day just work out eat healthy foods <end>

title: <start> experiencing odd symptoms , not sure what these could be <end>
response: <start> not a therapist but i also get like that with my arms . i am in my mid s , have had anxiety since , well forever . it does feel like they are not attached to my body . i have had that happen for years and i am still here and for the most part sane . i think it is called depersonalization . i also at times feel spaced out like i am not here and i am just observing from above . your sense of smell gets extremely sensitive when your highly anxious , it is a primitive reaction from when we actually had to worry about predators . dizzy and feeling weak and faint is also commonly caused by anxiety . some days my legs shake so bad i can not walk far . google physical symptoms caused by anxiety and all these things you have described will be on there . with all that said , you do really need to see a professional . it helps so much to talk it out and learning healthy coping skills . you feel safer and just relief that help is there . most communities have free mental health service programs especially for adolescents . <end>

title: <start> i went back to therapy for the first time in months , and my experience left me very unsettled . <end>
response: <start> whatever you do , please , do not go back to that therapist . i do not know you and i rarely give such immediate feedback to anonymous questions , but this i can tell you for sure this was not psychotherapy . in no first session ever does a therapist lecture their client on anything unless they are in immediate danger , and even then , they do it carefully , trying to build trust and rapport . this therapist did not seem to even care about empathizing with you , and i believe she has some negative counter transference regarding dads or kids or i do not really know . based on this description , not only you will not build rapport , but you might make your issues and your self esteem even worse . if you absolutely need to continue seeing her , you can mention how she made you feel . you can even politely ask her to not give her parenting advice when she is not asked to , as you are not there for your child s mental health but for your own . also , i am sure you are a great dad . <end>

title: <start> will a therapist involuntarily commit me to a psychiatric hospital if i express suicidal ideation <end>
response: <start> there are several aspects of ideation . . . thinking about not being alive , thinking of suicide , planning the act , intent to act , preparation getting supplies , making a will , writing a note , etc , having a timeline , dry runs , attempt , etc . an involuntary admission is usually a last resort to protect you from yourself when you are actively suicidal . without a plan and without intent you almost certainly will not be sent to the hospital . even with a plan , most therapists will not send you . you can lookup suicide risk assessments on google to get an idea of how you will be evaluated . the therapist may work on a suicide safety plan with you you can google this too . look up potential therapists on psychology today . com and make sure the one you pick has experience with suicidal ideation and is not a rookie . you want someone who is comfortable with some risk and will not freak out when you mention the s word . <end>

title: <start> how much depression warrants going back on meds <end>
response: <start> talk with a psychiatrist therapist . my advice would be , if anything , get a low low dosage . right now i have to ween myself off the dose i am on , and it is hard . if you have been off months , but need it , i would try low dosage , and if you do not see improvement , you might just have to bite the bullet and start again with a higher dosage . whatever it takes . <end>

title: <start> what can i do and how do i trust a new therapist long <end>
response: <start> hi not a therapist but i thought i would comment . i am trans too it sounds like you have a lot of trauma and unexplained symptoms and could really benefit from working with a therapist . also if you are having a hard time with your memory i suggest you start journaling . i have a poor memory and i journal everyday so i can remember what happened and keep track of my symptoms . i recently got sober and it is helped a lot with keeping my mind clear so i would suggest you try being sober for a while , does not have to be forever but maybe try it for days or so . trusting a new therapist is really hard and i am struggling with the same thing right now , it can just take time for some people , i feel like i do not really start opening up until i have been with a new therapist for at least a month or so , sometimes longer . you should try seeing someone and stick with it for as long as you can . if it feels like they are not the right fit for you and you will not ever be able to trust them you can always try seeing someone else . <end>

title: <start> ever googled something a client talked about <end>
response: <start> i had a client a number of years ago that had a boyfriend that she claimed was famous in the field of forensic psychology . he allegedly had developed an assessment method for people i want to keep this very general for ethical reasons . she mentioned his name and was surprised that i had never heard of him . every so often she would ask if i had googled his name . i had not because it was irrelevant regarding therapy but we did explore her need to be recognized and valued for having a famous boyfriend . so therapy finally ended and some years went by and one day i was googling something and the thought popped up regarding my former clients boyfriend . i remembered his name and googled it . it turns out her boyfriend was quite famous in the field , the only problem was that he had violently killed himself about years earlier . this completely freaked me out , to say the least . the irrational part of me thought my client was dating a ghost . <end>

title: <start> am i working out out of shame <end>
response: <start> this is an interesting question and one i would imagine many people have . thank you for submitting it for some context , i am new to reedit , trained as a clinical social worker , and currently work as a behavioral health clinician in an integrated care setting to provide short term counseling to pediatric and adult patients i suppose a way to explore this is to practice identifying and sitting with your personal motivations . what drives you to work out what does exercise mean to you what have your exercise patterns been over time have they changed if so , what else was going on around those times what external messages about your body lifestyle routines do you receive or believe you might be susceptible to based on your life experience once we have marinated on that , i wonder if it could be helpful to explore what feelings or emotions are tied to those motivations . for example , if the thought is , i am driven to work out because i want to be more toned , an associated feeling could be anything from anxiety i am anxious because my body does not look like i want it to . to inspired i have access to equipment and am excited to see what my body is capable of . these are just examples . the point is our thoughts about a thing impact our feelings about ourselves others the world which then inform how we behave . there are endless competing messages circulating about what a person should or should not do with their body . it is no surprise navigating this would because personal reflection or even distress . you know yourself best . it is cool you are thinking this through and i wish you kindness to both your mind and body as you explore it interested to hear others thoughts , as well , and happy to post some resources related to body image , shame , eating behaviors , etc . if desired . <end>

title: <start> why does my mom walk around the house with her pants off <end>
