title: <start> how can i make objective observations of myself if all i ever feel about myself is self doubt <end>
response: <start> therapy would be really helpful here , and i am glad you are considering it . one technique that comes to mind is cut , which you can actually look at online particularly cognitive restructuring which is basically challenging your negative thoughts about yourself to more realistic ones . self doubt is totally natural , but it does become unhealthy when it is impacting your mood and your self esteem . the other thing you could try is journaling , or keeping a notebook . one option is writing down your feelings journaling is seriously good therapy . the other idea is writing down what you did well . what are the things you are proud of today what are the things that can book future self doubt on the head it might feel weird at first , but getting yourself into that pattern and seeing things on paper can make a world of difference . good luck . <end>

title: <start> would it be weird to ask my therapist to come with me when i get a tattoo <end>
response: <start> it is not weird to feel connected to your therapist . that says a lot about the both of you . unfortunately it would be inappropriate for her to attend such an event at this time . sorry to be a bummer but your therapist really should maintain professional boundaries with you . congratulations on your progress and completing the top program <end>

title: <start> am i a commitment probe <end>
response: <start> nope , it just sounds like he is not for you . sounds like you need to learn more about yourself , and take the time you need to learn how to be content being alone first . not because you will be alone forever , but because if you are not content being alone , you will never really be content when you are with someone . what you are doing is trying to find a sense of wholeness through other people , through finding a boyfriend . this is really common , hell it is the premise of most disney movies , but it is just plain wrong . our desire to feel whole , and feel connected with others is so strong that if we are not careful we can do ourselves harm by not staying true to who we are . when you go after finding an other with this mentality this is when you might lose sight of the big picture who you are , what you want out of life and out of a partner . you also risk bending who you are , your morals , what you deem is respectable treatment , in a negative direction . of course we change and learn and grow , and an ideal partner would be a part of that lifelong process , they would change and learn and grow alongside you . but if it is not leading to positive change , or if positive change is being hindered because a partner a actively discourages it , it is time to end it from what i gather from your situation . it seems as though you are idealizing this person in your mind right when you meet them , which is a fiction . it is an fictional version of this person , this force , who you imagine in some way will make you feel whole . this is a way you create expectations of someone in your own head . then as you spend more time together , they do not meet your expectations and you get mad at them or start resenting them . but you stay together because you believe in this little fiction , this image of them you have created . this image is not real , it is false . when you meet someone you know very little about them . they are story , their complexes , their insecurities , their motivations , desires and dreams , their fears , traumas , the things they are avoiding looking at themselves , what they think they might be missing to feel whole . these things are not a part of your fiction , but they are a part of your real life experience . it becomes imagined expectation versus reality . they will not be in sync . just relax , learn all about you and enjoy being you . you are already whole even if you do not feel it at the moment . when you are living your fullest life , reaching for your dreams , following a career path , playing your sports or your instruments , learning , growing , and bettering yourself , surrounding yourself with people whose energy just plain sings alongside your own whatever it is you do the right person will be on the same path as you already , with all the same interests , and all the same good , healthy habits , and they will be someone who likes growth and change . and neither of you will feel like you need the other , you will already feel full . the other will only be a compliment to your already wonderful life . probably more of a response than what you were expecting or wanting , but here you go . all the best . . . side note , this is why i do not like disney , all the stories do is teach a terrible kind of relationship pattern . <end>

response: <start> thank you so much for this comment . it was like a cold shower . the only thing i want to point out is that i do enjoy being by myself but i do get quite lonely at times . but you are right , we should feel whole by ourselves and if we do find someone that someone would compliment our life and not fill it as if it was half a life . i guess i was just confused because while he seems like a nice guy and all i still don t like him and people around me , from my family to my friends have told me i ll die alone and that i have high standards and it hurts , you know i only want someone to get me , to like me for me but more often than not i don t feel a connection , a spark to someone that happens to like me . and i know sometimes the spark does not come and it just takes a while to fall for someone . i could benefit from seeing a therapist , i think . and i agree , disney movies offer a very unrealistic set of expectations which is why i never ever took them as models of what to expect in real life . <end>

title: <start> did i just have an anxiety or panic attack <end>
response: <start> they are actually the same thing . you had a panic attack which is the formal name given to an experience of overwhelming anxiety . <end>

title: <start> they are actually the same thing . you had a panic attack which is the formal name given to an experience of overwhelming anxiety . <end>
response: <start> this unvoted . op , from what you are saying , certainly sounds like it . a panic attack has nothing to do with overreacting . by the time anyone has a panic attack , it is completely out of their control . essentially what happens is that all of your adrenaline gets dumped into your bloodstream at once . once this happens , all you can try to do is use coping skills to make yourself as comfortable as you can until it passes . no matter how bad , it will always pass with time because the adrenaline does not stay effective for very long and most folks bodies do not produce it quickly enough to keep it pumping for long once you have used up all your stores . you can not prevent or stop it once it is started , however you can take steps to make sure you do not get to that point beforehand and make plans so you know exactly what to do to make yourself as comfortable as possible if when it happens . <end>

title: <start> too clingy instant attachment <end>
response: <start> i think it is a bit hard to give a reason without knowing more about you nothing is ever clear cut . yes , attachment plays a big part with our families being key in forming those patterns . yet there is a big spectrum of healthy . you may have had normal parents , but still managed to pick up on different behaviours or patterns . attachment can also be shaped from later in life like the relationships with students , teachers etc , the way we think , feel and the environment that we grow up in . maybe it is worth getting curious about what sort of stuff runs through your mind when you feel like your getting clingy and trying to change things that way . . <end>

title: <start> ethics of sharing among therapists <end>
response: <start> not at all i think it is probably worth chatting to your therapist s and getting some clarification on what is being shared and where your confidentiality lies or how they work as a team . every therapist works differently so there might not be a right or wrong answer , but you absolutely have the right to see what is being disclosed and to stop those disclosures if need be . <end>

title: <start> self hate , guilt and loneliness <end>
response: <start> i am not a psych but i noticed this did not have any comments so i thought i might chime in . i know where you are at at i was alone and struggling and thinking i was a terrible person etc . i had some friends in the beginning , but they left me . i was a lone wolf in elementary , i was a lone wolf in middle , and , yes , i have remained one in high school . i still talk to them , but they always invent a reason just to leave me . yeahhhh , woo do i ever know this story dude . i am years older but this is basically what my life was in school . people would pity me but then realize nobody else wanted to be around me for a reason . the teachers ignore me , they do not consider me as something special . yeah , people think teachers are heroes , but they are just overworked daycare workers . i actually did really shitty in school dropped out but later completed an adult program , one of my teachers said to me after i deleted my work and said it was terrible , that if you actually did your work you would be better at it nah , i thought it was terrible because i was taught everything i did was bad or unimportant my entire life . my parents are stressing me with good marks my parents work hard and come home very late . i can not talk to them , especially my mother . she criticizes me for every little thing i do . sorry for this a lot of parents are not good at their job . depending on what it is , your mother may be emotionally abusing you . going by the sort of things you say here it is been like this every single day and every single week . it is all my fault . i hate myself . i am stupid and i do not want to see my face anymore . you can hate me if you want . you have the right . it is i who did the wrong , not you . it is likely that is what is happening . very common unfortunately . what did you do wrong , exist you only learned to do what you were taught . you should look into childhood emotional abuse and when you are old enough , leave and get away from under your parents ire . <end>

title: <start> when do you know you have to take meds <end>
response: <start> therapists typically do not have as in depth of a background of medications as we cannot prescribe medication . medication can be effective for treatment when paired with therapy . as she recommended , if it is something you are interested in , i would say you should seek a psychiatric nurse practitioner or psychiatrist . a good way to think about it is that medication chemically gets you to feeling the way you want to feel while therapy figures out and deals with the reasons behind why you were feeling that way . i hope this helps . <end>

title: <start> how do i stop feeling like a problem , a burden or inconvenience how do i stop venting and then feeling guilty or feeling guilty about a ton of things and hating myself affirmations feel false , unhelpful , and stupid . i am tired of living , at least like this . <end>
response: <start> i would suggest you look into reading some bren brown books as a place to start she also has some great ted talks and videos on couture . i have not assessed you , so can not speak specifically , but feelings of shame and guilt are something bren brown studies and writes about . she talks about people not feeling like they are enough , and these feelings lead people to feel like they are a burden to others , and guilty about having needs . if you are tired of living , i suggest getting into a face to face therapist as soon as possible , because no general book or vague internet advice is going to get to the root of your specific challenges . gratitude is something bren brown talks about , and is shown to be effective long term in a lot of ways . practice by recognizing three things you are grateful for everyday . they can be simple at first . i am grateful for the blue sky , that pretty flower , my dog , this coffee , ice cream , etc . as you get better , recognize and find gratitude in things that give your life meaning . a friend , family member , job , hobby , sport , skill , etc . and then what it is about those things that help you , such as team work , someone to talk to , somewhere to be , something to do , pride , feelings of accomplishment , money to pay the bills , etc the road ahead is going to be difficult , but worth it . know that you can do hard things , and that your life has value , because you are a human . it is a given , not something that needs to be earned . talk to yourself in a way you would talk to a small child you care about . or the way you talk to your pet . someone who you would speak kindly to when they are struggling . be gentle to yourself <end>

response: <start> i am going to respond to your question with a question . what caused you to respect the people in the group , and give them a voice other than the negative self thought talk towards yourself , what did they do to deserve it anything maybe some did , but my guess is mostly that you recognize they have value as humans . you are the same . you have value , because you are human . it is not something you need to earn , or that you need to deserve . you just have it . you are already enough . although , i do know that knowing is one thing , and believing is another . if you can not believe it yet , know that i believe it . i know that trusting yourself can be an incredibly hard step . it sounds like you know something happened to you that is being denied by others . honestly , it does not matter what others perception is , trust that you felt hurt scared violated abused whatever happened , and that those who can not see it , do not want to or can not because of their own challenges . also , whatever your addiction , know that substance abuse is a symptom . it does not define you , your feelings are likely overwhelming you , and numbing out helps . i use food . and my own treatment has been really hard , and feeling feelings is so hard . progress is not linear , relapse is part of recovery . you are not broken , there is nothing wrong with who you are , you have just been hurt so much . you are parents sound like douchebags . you do not need to justify yourself to them . be who you were born to be <end>

title: <start> are there any techniques to handle prodromal hypersexuality <end>
response: <start> so for starters i totally understand why you were reluctant to share this detail with your psychiatrist , but please tell him about the mania it is always uncomfortable to reveal those parts of yourself to a new person , but it is important for your wellbeing that he knows everything so can set you on the right medication path . wellbutrin is actually contraindicated for someone with any history of mania because it can spark episodes or make typical manic symptoms worse in some folks . definitely keep taking it as prescribed , do not stop taking anything , but you should absolutely talk to your doctor about the mania as soon as you can . <end>

title: <start> is it normal to talk about sex in therapy <end>
response: <start> none of this sounds particularly unusual to me given the issues you were bringing in . i have done a fair amount of sex therapy for myself , and there were definitely questions about what made me climax , who i wanted to have sex with , what i was going to do , things i was going to try , and so on . the only thing that sounds odd is there were goals to have sex with particular people , although it would probably make some kind of sense if you were saying you wanted to have sex with those people . one thing that maybe still seems confusing to you is that your therapist embraced your promiscuity praising you for having sex with new partners , but to me that reads as being sex positive . she wanted you to have good feelings about sex and your sexuality for the rest of your life , not to be beating yourself up for experimenting with lots of different partners . that is how i read this . <end>

title: <start> terminating clients <end>
response: <start> that really depends on many factors . the bottom line is that both client and therapist need to be motivated for it to work . just like a client can have many reasons to end therapy , so can a therapist . that said , i think a therapist does have the responsibility to advice and support the client on how to proceed with , if any , different therapy to a certain extent . you can not force a therapist to help you just like they can not force a client to be helped . <end>

title: <start> i nearly got hit by a truck today . <end>
response: <start> hello , i am a counselor not currently practicing , and i also have a family and personal history with struggling with depression , so i come at this question from both sides . x b first , your courage and openness are commendable and so healthy . coming forward to share and seek an opinion is the strongest thing you could do , because it directly responds to what your deep intelligence even deeper than the feelings or lack of them knows you deserve to feel well and to recover a sense of love for yourself , your life and enjoy living it more . that is all true . the feelings you describe are very typical and i also relate to the ways depression can disturb the brain s ability to feel pleasure , interest , and normal emotions which help us both enjoy and protect our lives . it seems like the way you chose to respond to your experience today was to turn it into a gift , a wake up call . you demonstrate your intelligence and deep strength by acting on that and writing here it seems like it helped you realize that the lack of feeling and concern is not how you know you want to be living , nor is it reflective of a happy , healthy brain and you are right . so , the next small step is to take another action and find , for example , a cut cognitive behavioral therapist , someone who might also have an existential spiritual set of tools to offer you , as well as considering other tools including possible medication but also simple behavioral and lifestyle changes to slowly and gently get your brain chemistry back into the normal range so that you can recover your aliveness , natural sense of joy , and love of life and yourself which every human is born to deserve . you can also find books or resources online , also amazing podcast , all free to help you get started with small changes but having a relationship dedicated to this a life coach is another great option would be really healing and helpful . we heal in relationship which helps us heal our relationships with ourselves as well . one small example there is a forum chat on psychcentral . com , for example i do not know it but just found it searching for something i write this all with great admiration for your courage and choice , you have already taken a strong step in the direction of health and recovery keep going , one step , one choice because we can not choose our original feeling , but we can choose how we respond to it what we do about or with it , one day at a time x b warmly and with very best wishes know you are not alone so many of us are working , growing , and learning to live more fully every day . depression is just an illusion and an exaggeration of truth , it is not the truth , our desire to live fully and love life is . p . smith <end>

response: <start> hello relikgrey , thank you so much for your great , open replies , they are so helpful and an honor to read . i agree with turkoman that you have definitely experienced several traumas and you are right , the interesting thing about healing ourselves is that often , the first steps are realizing and having others support us that there is in fact something to heal . again , your choice to recognize that even if it was not a rational act it is often a bigger intelligence which we have to listen to which i call our existential spiritual intuitive . that deep intelligence we do not even have to understand but we have to choose to listen it is pushing us to heal , to reach out for support , to open up even when we do not feel like it , we resist healing , or we feel too closed to let others in somehow , we make the choice and that makes us true heroes because this is the path to love and a full life what every human needs and most wants , covered up by the pain and our ego fear false independence desire for control . x b your description of your experiences of trauma can be seen in many things , some but not all of them you described were being beaten the sudden change of country and being completely unable to integrate for a couple of years due to language barrier the attempt to expose your vulnerable and beautiful courage to write a girl you liked by a friend who either was just curious or possibly lacked emotional maturity and so , some sensitivity and respect for your boundaries we all have to learn and grow and forgive others for what we are , too just imperfect humans . in addition , being an adolescent is a very big growth and challenging phase adding your relocation of culture , not just of home , as well as losing the continuous presence of your father are all real stress loads that can add to our trauma response . please see next reply for my own mini story of being traumatized over a series of years built up by several life events simply the atmosphere of my family that accumulated over time as another example for you to reference if it might help you x b a note here being adolescent boys , they often are following their egos fear and insecurity masked by an attempt to control instead of open up and love so they bully themselves and others into covering up the most beautiful parts of themselves their vulnerabilities , needs , and tender emotions i am sorry that happened to you , and is very common emotional bullying towards boys . mostly , boys with strong emotional spiritual intelligence and critical thinking can see through the fake versions of masculinity and resist the pressure to shut down their feelings , and know that their sensitivity and vulnerability are what make them most capable of love and fulfillment . x b when you talk about not being able to feel anything but some physical sensations instead of emotions now , and maybe a bit of tenderness and a bit of anger , you make me think of a condition called anepithymia which means the inability to have words for feelings , and the feeling of not experiencing emotions , but rather , bodily sensations , or having a very limited range of emotions anger sexual feelings , for example . and this is very common among males through the socialization process . boys are officially trained and bullied to not maintain their natural , inborn emotional intelligence , and pressured to display false control toward others aggression like in the fights you mentioned and even the sparring in martial arts with your friend , and toward themselves covering up denying and then eventually , training themselves to stop even feeling , their own tender , beautiful , vulnerable emotions and that means they lose contact with even what is happening except to feel anger or sexual drive . sexual drive is designed to be connected to the heart and our deep human natural need for connection bonding and intimacy , it is not a physical act . anger is not ever really only anger it is most often a secondary emotion which means , it is a defensive emotion that arrives to try to protect us from something more real like sadness , embarrassment , shame , fear , guilt , etc . if we let anger be a messenger hi , anger what are you here to teach me and not a leader i feel angry , therefore i stay defensive and act on it then it can serve us because we can understand and choose how to use it often , that means either to set a healthy boundary i get angry because someone does not respect my emotional or physical safety , or to express an underlying vulnerability i get angry , i slow down , breathe , take a break and reflect and realize i am sad and scared , and i allow that , do not cover it up , do not lash out in anger , and choose to share those feelings with the person i trust , and have empathy and compassion for myself and accept them as part of my being an emotionally healthy , strong human being who is committed to growth and health . x b feeling agitated or annoyed by dumb or loud people listen to jason gaddis about emotionally unavailable man and toxic masculinity because he talks about how when he was not in his own heart , everything annoyed him . i can say that for myself , not being a man , i also have that happen when i am depressed or just not taking good care of myself . i get easily annoyed and my lovely sensitivity becomes a burden because my nervous system is maxed out . you can read online or books about sensitivity and what a gift it is elaine aaron is wonderful and the author , also has online tests but , like a ferrary , you have to know how to take care of a highly tuned nervous system so it serves you well . x b when you talk now about violent and angry feelings , but also tender love feelings , and your desire to express love to your family even through something as simple as a genuine smile of appreciation for a gesture of your dad s love in cooking for you , or happiness for your mom s special occasion , that is where your deep soul is crying out to be freed from the she will of ego . that is your natural , true , loving nature you were born with . it is your health calling you into a new vision for yourself . it is asking you , i believe , to choose growth and love as your path . those are the choices that lead to happiness . you can choose love , and choose growth . x b sometimes , instead , we have an emergency and we need extra outside learning tools support that we have not found yet . so , we create a she will wall in order to survive for an emergency time until we get support and tools to thrive , and not just survive . they are called defenses , and they serve an important purpose short term until we can get help , grow , and heal . x b meaning when you went through these difficult experiences traumas which means anything that negatively significantly impacts and blocks our abilities to cope and thrive and shuts us down or makes us resort to emergency , more short term coping skills that are not optimal , you turned down your feelings so you would not be overwhelmed by them . that was smart as an emergency move . but it is not the best you can do long term , it costs you too much in terms of joy and developing empathy and connection and satisfaction in life . x b you certainly need to learn , study , practice , and also get therapy help life coaching there indeed are good enough and even excellent ones out there and we always have time for what is most important in life your brain is very flexible plastic at your age so now is the time to do this so you have a life of happiness and high functioning ahead of you , instead of stunting your emotional existential health and growth and then having chronic problems and unhappiness later in life . . . academic success is important , but it does not prepare us to have fulfilling , thriving lives . you are too smart emotionally not to see that x b the things you have already identified to grow are being able to feel and identify a range of positive emotions , receive and give love and connection , feel courage around your vulnerable feelings , manage and recognize the real emotions beneath anger , and thus , not need to use aggression to cover up real human needs and desires for love , happiness , connection , and learn how to heal and take care of the little not even have to understand but we have to choose to listen it is pushing us to heal , to reach out for support , to open up even when we do not feel like it , we resist healing , or we feel too closed to let others in somehow , we make the choice and that makes us true heroes because this is the path to love and a full life what every human needs and most wants , covered up by the pain and fulfillment . x b when you talk about not being able to feel anything but some physical sensations instead of emotions now , and maybe a bit of tenderness and a bit of anger , you make me think of a emotions anger sexual feelings , for example . and this is very common among males through the socialization process . boys are officially trained and bullied to not maintain their natural , inborn except to feel anger or sexual drive . sexual drive is designed to be connected to the heart and our deep human natural need for connection bonding and intimacy , it is not a physical act . anger is , fear , guilt , etc . if we let anger be a messenger hi , anger what are you here to teach me and not a leader i feel angry , therefore i stay defensive and act on it then it can serve us because we health . x b feeling agitated or annoyed by dumb or loud people listen to jason gaddis about emotionally unavailable man and toxic masculinity because he talks about how when he was not in his own heart , everything annoyed him . i can say that for myself , not being a man , i also have that happen when i am depressed or just not taking good care of myself . i get easily annoyed and my lovely sensitivity becomes a burden because my nervous system is maxed out . you can read online or books about sensitivity and what a gift it is elaine aaron is wonderful and the author , also has online tests but , like a ferrary , you have to know how to take care of a highly tuned nervous system so it serves you well . x b when you talk now about violent and angry feelings , but also tender love response: <start> my trauma history reply to your thoughts about therapists i had a clear symptom of a history of trauma that built up but did not appear until i was . and at the time , neither i nor anyone in my family still recognized it . before this my parents had divorced when i was , and my mom remarried when i was , we changed religions not drastically , but this still represented a break with family tradition and security . my mom and stepped were not in any way abusive or actively hurting me , and yet , there was a constant level of stress in strain in their relationship very critical , negative , and always arguing , but not yelling , my mom had depression we did not know it at the time , but now it makes sense so was extra critical and negative all the time picking apart what we did and very rarely having a kind or encouraging interaction or warmth , and my dad , who was much more emotionally healthy and warm , was far away in another state and we saw him only a couple of times a year . i did not know or feel it consciously at the time until much later as an adult , when i started to cry and grieve this period , but i was living in a bit of an emotional desert , being very sensitive and affectionate but not having much warmth , intimacy , or simply positive interaction with the family around me . i spent time with my dog , nature god , and my best friend . and then we moved houses not once but twice , and finally , moved states not once but twice . my dad stayed in my life this whole time , but by the time we moved the last time , it was too much for my sensitive system . it is like i ran out of inner happy fuel the fuel i had built up from my happy early childhood , my connection with my dad , and surviving by spending time with my dog nature god and my best girl friend before our move . so , i had a bit of an identity crisis . i was a junior in high school and had to start completely over no friends , no support system , and a completely different culture much less dramatic than yours , so just have empathy for how stressful yours was for your system in the sense of a different social cultural area of the united states , and that was a big deal , because it made me see myself differently and feel insecure and i had no best friend left her behind with the move to give me a sense of my secure world . i am also an introvert , so i do not need a lot of friends , but i do need them , and it makes it hard for me to open up and feel comfortable in busy group situations which all means , it makes it hard to meet new people in a new big school . add to this i was starting to question our new religion which was the other rock in my family s life and it all was too much . i became depressed for the first time in my life i stopped taking good care of my grooming , of my room , i lost motivation to do homework i was an excellent student up until then and never had moodiness that interfered with my life , and though i thought i was generally happy , i was , i also had a low level of melancholy and wanted to kind of withdraw too much , not going outside or just feeling at ease in life in my down time . the time i finally began recognizing the trauma i am continuing to learn from it and use it to heal myself and others i seemed to recover by the time i graduated high school , and went on to college , but my sense of angst and depression just came back because moving away to college , facing a whole new culture there , and being separated from home and my dog my best friend , very real and family , were all lots of stressors i was not ready for , and my big religious questions , combined with my lack of emotional nurturing at home over the years , and i went to therapy for the first time . the therapist who interviewed me first was terrible , but he luckily referred me to a wonderful doctor , named dr . smart who was warm , gentle , kind , and an amazing , quiet and soft listener . this is what i needed , and , with a small group of gentle and kind friends , i grew healthier and also found a wonderful support in the university department i chose to study in art in a couple of gentle and loving professors . where was the trauma it was small , slow , and mostly built of neglect what was missing , not what was actively done . and then , small chronic mini stressors that , built up over years , are trauma , because they ask an overload of effort on the emotional spiritual system to survive , and do not feed , nurture , and support growth and thriving . that is the difference to survive or to thrive . this challenge of depression is something that i continue to have to work with all these years later , and has improved so much with my learning studying getting help and support sharing with very close and trusted friends family , and practicing the best , most important decisions i have ever made are to say no to my ego and become humble and look for , study , and ask for help and accept support and the discomfort of growing . it has made all the difference , and is the only way to free ourselves from the ego control fear anger trap and live freely as love giving and receiving , joyful , real people . just like when we were smaller kids an additional note you did not come out and say it directly , but from your description of therapy and your comment about low quality in the you . s . , it seems like your experience opening up and trusting someone with that therapist ended up not working to give you concrete tools , real empathy , and some practical support when in fact you needed it . you are right that not all therapists are equal , just like doctors are not i have found that in both cases , when you have a clear need not just a simple annual checkup , for example , it is best to shop around that does not mean dropping one when you get frustrated that is part of learning to work through relationships and we practice in therapy what it does mean is that doing a first session with a couple of different therapists from different styles or training can really help if at first you do not click . and asking questions interviewing the therapist not the whole time , also trying out a mini session and seeing how it sits with you . <end>

response: <start> hey again page . i too am this year and have only begun to notice what seems wrong with me . thinking back , i do not remember the last time i had genuinely laughed . the reason i stopped going for therapy sessions is that my mother could not afford it . she could have but i told her that she was better off using the money for my future . i am graduating next months and i may book a session using my own money . but i can not guarantee it will be a monthly or even a weekly routine . i understand that moving is hard for you , and from what i have read , this took place maybe years ago . i hear that psychology takes a hefty amount of time to study and you said you were a counselor but not yet practicing so i can safely assume you are maybe about ish years old . i understand that leaving your best friend was hard as i had left several good friends of mine . but for me , its easier with today s technology and i believe that several decades ago , saying you were moving to a different or continent was a commitment and you will likely not see each other again . i am leaving for college in the coming months and i believe that my experience will be similar to yours but maybe i will feel either nothing or fear . i hope i get the same opportunity as you to meet good professors that are nice and kind . as for trauma , i feel like i have not been through any . and if i did , it took place years ago and i really only began to feel dead inside years ago . the fights with that person did not change me . i felt changed after the session with the therapist . she told me to let out all my feelings on paper and to do it daily . i did it once and here i am today . edit i will reply to this comment in the morning with a clearer head as i am not really thinking straight . i will get to answering anything you have mentioned in your comment . <end>

response: <start> hi again , thanks for taking the time to share your thoughts . here s the problem thoughts are not everything . they do not make us either fully intelligent , nor fully human . humans , and other animals , are by nature both reason feeling beings , plus will choice decision commitment to values . you must decide to be humble you have already expressed great capacity to do this and to overcome your ego in the past an avoid puffing yourself up and in doing this , you will become a student of life , and of emotions . deciding to become falsely unemotional is not a solution , just like deciding not to eat would be unhealthy . you must choose to learn , study not as a therapist , as a human being committed to growth and health , and seek support and help in doing so . that way , you will not allow yourself will certain behaviors based on emotion , including your fear of emotion which has led you to try to cut it off completely . it is okay at the time , you did not realize , and your mother and therapist did not either . you were probably good at convincing her and yourself , but it was not an honest choice , since you clearly needed to grow and be supported , like we all do . it is okay and normal to be overwhelmed and scared when we are learning something it is natural . strong people embrace that fear and feel it , and do the right thing and the courageous thing , which is to ignore the ego and choose to love and grow . to do that , like when you learn a new sport or a new subject at school , you get good books , you study , you practice , and you get good teachers . and you accept the discomfort and the struggle , right it does not stop you from wanting to get good at it . emotions are no different , and even more important you will become a martial artist of happiness and connection and joy . of satisfaction , pride in who you are as a character , and peace . instead , by blocking emotions and stopping support , you actually accidentally stunted your growth , like stopping taking vitamins . reading more about your experience with your therapist , it sounds like the writing down of all the emotions , and then abruptly stopping therapy , was overwhelming . you chose to intellectualize and decide to block them . that is not a healthy or sustainable choice . finances would have been better spent on your future through therapy . your future is not financial academic , but the whole reality of your mental emotional physical health , which are all related . intellectualization and denial are defenses which do not serve us long term . therapy and working on ourselves helps us develop real coping skills which allow us to thrive , not just get by . right now , that is what you get to choose to do thrive , and stop just surviving , because you woke up to the truth that something is not right in your choice , years ago , to defend against your emotions by trying to shut them down . clarification going to therapy does not mean one has mental illness . it means one is smart , recognizes areas that need to grow , and finds a way to heal and grow them faster and better through support . it is a sign of strength and intelligence to know our limitations and seek to grow . period . trauma is difficult , taxing experience . and it does not always have immediate noticeable effects . it also accumulates over time . and can be suddenly coming to a crisis like the one you had when you decided to shut down and stop therapy . that choice was also a defense you intellectualized it was financial , but it was fear of doing the work and being uncomfortable , too . and both of those feelings are okay and normal , but we have to choose to grow , and that requires us choosing to be humble and be students of life to learn how to handle our emotions healthily . in fact , your mentioning if you were to take a life is an indication of what happens when we make unhealthy , defensive choices in dealing with our emotions we stop functioning intelligently and well . you must decide that will never be an option , no matter how you feel or do not feel . that is will . and then , you work to awaken your natural , inborn emotional intelligence by learning , getting support , and practicing , one day at a time . that is how to avoid mental illness , suffering , and poor life choices . you cannot talk about a future without talking about yourself as a whole , emotional mental physical spiritual person . that is true for all of us . you have got a great heart , now grow it , and grow it up into the love you are and were born to feel . <end>

title: <start> could my therapist be gaslighting me <end>
response: <start> i can not tell by your post whether your therapist is gaslighting , but it is clear that you are both not a good fit for each other . there is every possibility there that her intentions are good but coming across all the wrong ways . i think it would be helpful to look for another to get some help . you could try humanistic or person centred therapy focuses around the client being an expert of their own lives , and aiming to work in a more collaborative approach . that way you can start to feel a little bit more in control . <end>

response: <start> you absolutely need to stop taking both at the same time . there is a drug interaction between bupropion and vortioexetine , because they are in the same drug class . if they are being taken at the same time in low doses , that needs to be monitored by a psychiatrist . the bupropion changes how your liver processes the vortioexetine . if it can not be processed properly , the side effects of the vortioexetine can be magnified . do not do anything before checking with your pharmacist or preferably psychiatrist , but do that as soon as possible . <end>

title: <start> attracted to my therapist <end>
response: <start> this is not uncommon at all . it is really up to you to decide if it is going to get in the way of doing the work but the best thing to do once you have mustered the courage is to talk about it with your therapist . it is not uncommon because more often than not , a good therapist is helping to meet some of the needs you have in your life that have gone unmet , possibly for a long time . they can represent an ideal parental figure , friend , or partner if you are attracted to them . the problem with this is that it is built on an ideal and not a reality . even if your therapist self discloses a lot , at the end of the day , you do not really know them , who they are , and what they are like outside of the professional setting . if they are a good therapist , you will never know . you are more likely in love with the idealistic image of them you have created than the person themselves . this can actually be really useful stuff to process and work through in therapy . in my experience both professional and person , it rarely does any good to keep things like this secret and bottled up . <end>

title: <start> therapist after a shooting <end>
response: <start> sounds like you are still in the shock denial phase after a traumatic event . this is normal , but your emotions or lack thereof may change suddenly . definitely counseling can be helpful if you feel any or all of you need it . perhaps the best approach would be to see if your child needs it , and you can join in a session or two as needed to help support her as a family . talking about the incident and related feelings is always helpful . good dad for asking these questions and caring about your daughter we all have different love languages there is a book on the love languages you can read or just google the concept . you just have a different love language than your wife . my husband is an acts of service guy and i am more physical touch and words of affirmation . nothing wrong with that hang in there and glad she is ok . <end>

response: <start> it is my superpower and my kryptonite . it helps most of the time , because it forces me to ask questions about how people feel about situations that if i had to guess or make an assumption about how they feel , i would have guessed wrong . also , it is strangely helpful in that i have a hard time understanding social taboos about talking about things like sex , or suicide , because for me , while those topics might be associated with strong feelings , i simply do not have a hard time addressing those topics . consequently , i think that i put people at ease because i am genuinely not bothered by the cultural context around taboo subjects . where it trips me up is that there are times when i miss body language or other cues that would have clued me in that my clients were shutting down , or getting angry , but fortunately that does not happen too often . or i can sort of freak people out with my bluntness . <end>

response: <start> thanks for your response . i know i could keep my mind busy with the activities you described , but from my perspective , that is escapism . i have smoked a lot of weed in the past and i quit a year ago . i have also quit alcohol months ago , gaming over months ago , and i barely watch any movies or tv shows . for me , these decisions have been some of the best i have made in my life . why did i quit all that i want to create a life that is worth living , one that is so awesome i do not need to escape from it . i do not think movies , smoking weed etc . can ever actually create true happiness and meet our true needs of community , achievement , etc . so i do not want to go back there . but yes , planning my day and keeping busy in a constructive way exercise , work , cleaning etc is a very good reminder . problem is , in terms of work , i work on my business , and overthinking gets me into analysis paralysis , so it is a bit of a vicious circle right there . . . thank you for your advice , i am glad your way works for you , but it is probably not quite for me . <end>

title: <start> i am scared of what happens after death . <end>
response: <start> am not a therapist but maybe this could help you . all life is a reflection of existence and the universe . we as human beings in a collective sense are personifications of the universe . all our good , all our bad , our thoughts , fears , actions . are simply a reflection of the chaotic insane beautiful impossible to comprehend reality of this remention of existence . now the most essential base rule of life is the first law of thermodynamics . nothing can be destroyed only changed . things fall apart and then they come together again . this is the endless beautiful cycle of the universe that we get to be apart of . it is literally impossible for your life to be extinguished . you will not end you will be transformed . you have been so many other things before you were you and you have faced death an endless amount of times and you will continue to endlessly until the universe itself collapses and is destroyed and eventually transformed anew . repeating the cycle again . i understand how scary it can be . we have all felt that unimaginable feeling of horror at some point in our lives . that deep indescribable fear that pierces your soul . the idea that that feeling could be waiting for us after death is horrifying but that just would not make any sense at all . existence is not vindictive or cruel . if it was life itself would not function . no matter what your state of existence there will be good and bad . same as your life now . one day you will be something or someone or just part of the very essence of the universe and you will not remember this life and that you were afraid . you will just exist . <end>

title: <start> counseling with a manipulator <end>
response: <start> sharp can do a consultation of her own . she should ask the therapist what their experience with personality disorders is . if the clinician is not experienced with those disorders , i think sharp should exercise her agency to find a different therapist if that is allowed . also , you friend will benefit from reading stop walking on eggshells . it is meant for people who live with someone who has borderline personality disorder , but i have found it to be helpful to anyone who has to deal with someone who is wildly inconsistent and emotionally manipulative . sidebar . here s how i handle people who try to bullshit me i perform the following mental gymnastics i start out assuming both people are being truthful . maybe there are just perceptions or memories that are off . if both are treated with the respect that their story is truthful to them , the therapist is then free to establish facts that sit outside of either narrative ie , the facts that are not subject to interpretation or spin . over time the therapist will notice who keeps their story consistent with the facts , and whose story changes as the facts are established . i am not sure if that is a recommended approach , just something i have done that has been effective at moving couples off of arguing about what happened or who is at fault , and into dealing with their shit . <end>

title: <start> i want to consult a therapist , but i am too afraid to . <end>
response: <start> talking with a mental health professional is never easy . . . it requires a level of vulnerability that many are uncomfortable with so , yay you are not alone also , as a mental health provider , i am very aware of this struggle and generally begin my sessions praising clients on their ability to open up and ask for help . initiating treatment is an anxiety inducing experience that should be validated by any skilled therapist . additionally , i just want to say wow . i am so impressed with the incredible insight you are displaying at your age go you processing through your emotional responses to situations is a significant strategy of growth . . . many of my adult clients lack the awareness you have . i have undoubted faith in your ability to manage whatever mental obstacles you experience . . . because you have already began the journey . i would encourage you to seriously consider talking with your school counselor . and if that sounds too intimidating right now which is completely understandable i might downloading a counseling app and exploring those options . remember you matter . you are valuable . and you deserve help if you need it . there are so many of us out there that understand and genuinely want to help however we can <end>

title: <start> is my problem serious enough for sex therapy <end>
response: <start> my wife had vaginismus , and we both would have benefited from an aspect therapist http www . aspect . org referral directory waylay sooner than when we went . it was still awesome . she got referred to better , more effective physical healthcare while getting care that was sensitive to the particulars of our situation . i should note that vaginismus , at least at the time she had it a few years back , not more than , was a pretty uncommon diagnosis , and we actually ended up at the mayo clinic after several wrong diagnoses this is just to give you an idea of how difficult it was even to get a correct diagnosis . the mayo gave her the right diagnosis and started her on effective medical care , but our therapist was actually the one who referred her to the treatment option that took her from functioning at an okay level to sex is finally , un reservedly awesome again so go see a sex therapist . <end>

title: <start> how to fix psychopathic tendencies ps am i a psychopath . . . <end>
response: <start> i am not sure if you meet the criteria for psychopath but you are definitely concerned that there is something wrong that you may need help for , so it would probably benefit you to get a therapist and say exactly what you said here . even if you do not tick all the boxes for any diagnoses , you listed specific areas in your life that are not functioning and you could take some meaningful steps to change all that with the right guidance . some of that you could have worked through significantly enough that you feel like a different person if you reread this next year . if you do nothing the gaps in social skills and executive functioning will just grow and become more permanent . you have quite a bit of insight about yourself , which means you are more likely to succeed in therapy than others . also , psychopathic would not mean bad as there are lots of successful people in the world with that label . it is the traits that hold you back that you need to develop . i hope you make an appointment for your future happiness . <end>

title: <start> when does a therapist have to contact police cps <end>
response: <start> i have a severely disabled child who will never sit , walk , talk , eat , his list of diagnoses is long today at age . but in his first year we did not know the extent of his disabilities . he was just being tested for things and evaluated by all the specialists and he was around months when i requested a copy of his mri results from his neurologist to take to his gastroenterologist that i was shocked into the reality of it all . the doctor did not tell me this , and i do not know why , but i began to read direct language about the damage to his brain birth injury . this left me online searching to figure out what this abnormality meant and what that one meant and what it meant if these three were combined . i stayed awake days straight finding all the worst case scenarios and it was like reliving the whole traumatic birth over again . . . only worse because now i knew he would never be okay . went to a psychiatrist to explain that i already had a ptsd diagnosis and i think i am experiencing similar symptoms regarding what is happening now . told her that i blamed myself for not knowing something was wrong in labor and at times believed i deserved to die for failing him . she asked me what would happen to my son then i said i do not know because we would been pretty isolated through all this and i guess he would never make it without me . she asks for my husband s work number and calls him at work to make him agree that i am no longer to be alone with my son . what that is not what i meant she did not even ask me anything to clarify what i meant despite seeing i was having a hard time talking about it . after that , i was never honest with any medical professional about my thoughts in that arena . and when he started having seizures , ended up on life support and diagnosed legally blind , my thoughts did progress to feelings of worthlessness and feeling like he should not have to live this way and maybe in heaven he would be whole again and i could hear him call me mommy . it was never a plan or something i had any intention of doing . it was just my struggling brain exploring any possible way out of the pain of my new reality . i know what you mean by these thoughts so i know you have no intention of hurting anyone . i believe you . my son is years old today not once in the decade that followed that despair did i ever entertain those thoughts . sometimes when someone is tailgating me i think about how i would like to slam on my breaks and teach them a lesson . . . nobody ever worried i would . every now and then i will tell my husband i would like a sister wife because there just is not enough of me to go around . i have never gone sister wife hunting . i just want a nap we have thoughts and so many are just fleeting thoughts to cope with current distressing situations with few visible options . do not beat yourself up over it . just deal with those thoughts when they come . brain , you do not actually mean that . let us reframe how i am really feeling . come up with other workable solutions to an issue that feels hopeless and that thought will have replacements to ponder . my brain loves to find worst case scenarios for all kinds of things husband s phone is tracked as not moving on the freeway he definitely was testing and driving and was in a fatal car accident . i have no idea how to be a single mom son has been sleeping harder than usual and has not budged on the monitor he had a seizure in his sleep and stopped breathing . can i hug him and kiss him goodbye or am i too scared to touch him knock on the door that is unexpected they are here to tell me someone had an accident and died or i am under arrest for some crime i did not even know i committed . i am always expecting a traumatic event around every corner . so my brain fills in the blanks . be prepared that when you talk to someone about it they may not understand exactly what you mean . that may mean you need to clarify or it may mean they get someone else involved . hopefully it will be heard the way you meant it . . . a ridiculous worst case scenario ending to a problem you have been unable to brainstorm realistic endings to . after you have had time to process your thoughts , where they came from and why , i hope that is enough for you to stop feeling guilty for your on the look out for worst case scenario seeking brain . <end>

despair did i ever entertain those thoughts . sometimes when someone is tailgating me i think about how i would like to slam on my breaks and teach them a lesson . . . nobody ever worried i would . every now and then i will tell my husband i would like a sister wife because there just is not enough of me to go around . i have never gone sister wife hunting . i just want a nap we have thoughts and so many are just fleeting thoughts to cope with current distressing situations with few visible options . do not beat yourself up over it . just deal with those thoughts when they come . brain , you do not actually mean that . let us reframe how i am really feeling . come up with other workable solutions to an issue that feels hopeless and that thought will have replacements to ponder . my brain loves to find worst case scenarios for all kinds of things husband s phone is tracked as not moving on the freeway he definitely was testing and driving and was in a fatal car accident . i have no idea how to be a single mom son has been sleeping harder than usual and has not budged on the monitor he had a seizure in his sleep and stopped breathing . can i hug him and kiss him goodbye or am i too scared to touch him knock on the door that is unexpected they are here to tell me someone had an accident and died or i am under arrest for some crime i did not even know i committed . i am always expecting a traumatic event around every corner . so my brain fills in the blanks . be prepared that when you talk to someone about it they may not understand exactly what you mean . that may mean you need to clarify or it may mean they get someone else involved . hopefully it will be heard the way you meant it . . . a ridiculous worst case scenario ending to a problem you have been unable to brainstorm realistic endings to . after you have had time to process your thoughts , where they came from and why , i hope that is enough for you to stop feeling guilty for your on the look out for worst case scenario seeking brain . <end>

title: <start> i need some advice on what kind of therapist to see . <end>
response: <start> the most important thing you need in a therapist is someone you feel comfortable with . with that being said , faith based does not necessarily mean that they will use spirituality with you if you are not religious so they should not be pushing their views on you . if your mom is willing to do therapy with you then family therapy would be great , but if you are planning on going yourself you do not need a family therapist . as far as the bds , as long as it is not interfering with your functioning and it is consensual , there is really no reason a therapist would be bothered by it . if you are interested it music and think music therapy would be helpful go for it . if that is not your thing and you just want traditional talk therapy you should not have any trouble finding a therapist . cognitive behavioral therapy is probably the most commonly used and that would probably be a great start . if you do not think it is working out , you can always switch therapists or ask about different approaches . i hope this helps and i wish you the best of luck on your therapeutic journey . <end>

title: <start> therapy is not helping me and i am not sure if it is me or the therapist <end>
response: <start> after reading this i agree that an online therapist might be a better option if that helps you avoid some of the sticky issues that come up with attachment . a part of me wonders if you run overtime you think you are becoming attached to someone , in which case perhaps you will start to feel that way even towards an online therapist . i would suggest giving yourself some kind of mental escape plan so that you can feel safe if you feel attachment feelings coming on . i do not know if that means sitting on a couch eating ben and jerry s chunky monkey or meditation , but have some kind of release valve when i feel this way , i will do this to help myself feel differently . part of this escape plan needs to be a stay plan too , as in , i will stay with this t for period of time without shutting down or running away . a key part of that is that you are in control and you get to set the time period . regarding forming healthy relationships with men , first you will need to be able to identify what a healthy male looks like , and what a healthy relationship with a male looks like . those can be very different for many people , so i suggest that as a topic in therapy . my personal fave example of a good relationship is ran reynards and blake lively http youth . be wudu og im . <end>

response: <start> well , you are at least halfway there if you know intellectually how to spot someone with no boundaries when you are in the moment . the next step would be to take the initiative and say , this is not good for me , and be willing to leave . in order to spot someone who is healthy , i mean , you kind of say it all in your comment . you look for someone who has boundaries . you look for someone who , when they have emotional issues , they can tell you what is bothering them without trying to make you fix them ie , they are open about their feelings , but also , and this is key , responsible for how they feel . you look for someone who is consistent . if they say the right things , do they do the right things and when you catch on that someone falls short of one of these items which may sound like i am setting you up to hunt for unicorns , but honestly , these are not very high standards then you have to be the one to say , i am better on my own than with this person . <end>

title: <start> how to talk to my parents about my mental health <end>
response: <start> mmmm . i do not really know your age , but in my experience , discussing my own mental health with my parents is a very bad idea because they are judgmental and unsupportive and they think they have all the answers they certainly are not professionals , nor are they anything close to having professional knowledge . your parents probably will not be any different from mine . so with that in mind , i might just say something along the lines of , does our health insurance cover counselors i think i would like to start going to one . if your parents are anything like mine , then that is literally all the information you should give them the specifics are not any of their business . and if you give them specifics , they might ask you about your mental health for the next five years , and i highly doubt you want that . <end>

title: <start> what is the best path for me to become a therapist <end>
response: <start> i do not know how selective every grad school is , but i was able to get in with my film degree and a long career in customer service . i did not understand it at the time , but when i interviewed for my graduate program they were scanning for things like self awareness , and an ability to conceptualize things like conflict in a systemic manner the systemic thinking is specific my training as a marriage and family therapist . anyway , i pretty much just strove to be as honest and transparent as i could , and i got in . since you seem to only be interested in being a master s level clinician , you have options in the us lock , lips , and left . i have zero clue what it takes to be an lips , but many , many lifts and locks that i know come from non psychology backgrounds and were able to get into grad programs for these license tracks . if you are in the united states you might want to look into providing services to under served rural communities when you graduate . there are still loan forgiveness programs for doing this , although not as robust as they once were . <end>

title: <start> f , seriously derailing my weight loss and feeling depressed <end>
response: <start> i hope this does not come across as judgmental , because i mean this from a place of love and care and empathy . i am not a therapist . i am a woman who recovered from an eating disorder , but still struggles with bingeing and restricting behaviours sometimes . to me , it seems like you posted this in askatherapist because you are aware that this is not a healthy mindset to have , and maybe you are hoping someone will tell you that , and that you do not need to lose weight . a therapist can not tell you how to lose pounds . you are already quite slim , and your issue here it seems is your restricting and bingeing and body dystrophia , not a need to lose weight . losing pounds will not make you body positive . university is extremely stressful , and it is difficult to eat well and take care of yourself . i advise that you look into getting a therapist who specializes in eating disorders to help you through this . recovery is a lifelong journey , and i wish you all the best <end>

title: <start> what type of therapy would be most beneficial <end>
response: <start> the most important thing is finding a therapist you are comfortable with . as the previous commenter states , most therapists are eclectic and will use different approaches for different clients . at least i think that is what they were getting at , which is a good suggestion because if you see someone who solely does cut and you do not like it then you would have to start over with someone else . based on what you stated i think there is a lot of approaches that could help . mindfulness and grounding techniques could help with emotional regulation so cut or debt would be a great start . you might also want to look into emir eye movement desensitization and reprocessing which sounds nuts at first but it is evidence based and essentially allows your brain to heal itself with a therapist as a guide . i hope this helps and i wish you the best of luck on your therapeutic journey . <end>

title: <start> is psychosis frequent with patients with bed if so , how and how does it differ from regular schizophrenia <end>
response: <start> what you are describing sounds more like paranoid ideation rather than the delusional paranoia that is typically experienced during psychosis . paranoid ideation is in fact a symptom of bed and is even amongst the diagnostic criteria in the dam . as for the hallucinations , this is not unheard of with bed . you could also potentially be looking at a case of co morbidity with an additional disorder or mental health issue . i would do some reading not too much online just google bed any symptom and wait until you are next therapy session . i wish you the best <end>

title: <start> first time going to a therapist how to make the most of it <end>
response: <start> you are right , i do not think you will get a complete feel in the first session since they may ask a bunch of questions as it will be your intake session . i personally from a financial perspective would not see two at a time . i would give it sessions at least before you make up your mind . of course , if right off the bat you know its not a match made in heaven then yes try a different therapist . just a thought from the other side as therapists it can be incredibly frustrating when a client expects us to resolve their issues right away . it will take time and a lot of work on your part . so do not expect them to resolve your problems right away , it will take time . however , if you are having second thoughts about the therapist you picked out ask yourself why . do they remind you of someone you know do they specialize in what you are seeking help with are you ready to work explore not at all trying to sound like a snob , but just some food for thought . <end>

title: <start> is my therapist afraid of my depression <end>
response: <start> how long have you been in therapy with him if it is not long , i would say give it some time or at the very least , ask him what work the two of you need to do in order to tackle the depression piece and gauge what you think you need to do from there . as a therapist , i have had countless clients come in and try to just dump out everything they have been holding in way too early sometimes during the first session . whenever i can , i try to get them to hold up , and explain to them that while i understand this is all really important to them and we will get to it , there are some things we need to do first . i need to make sure that they have a good set of healthy coping skills in order to manage feelings that come up while we are processing this stuff . it is not uncommon to initially feel worse immediately after leaving a therapy session , especially when you have gotten in to some deep stuff . it is important for me to know that the client will be able to cope with these feelings . next , it is important that we actually have a relationship , that they see me as a person , and more importantly , see me as a person they can trust based off of more than just the fact that i am a therapist . if you have only been in therapy with him for a month or so , i would say give it some more time , but like i said , ask him when and how he will be ready to address this and under what circumstances . he owes it to you to be honest . whatever his answer is , you can use that to decide if you want to find a new therapist . keep in mind , what your impulses tell you that you want are not always in line with what you need or what would be best for you . in the end , trust whatever decision you make , but only after giving it careful consideration . <end>

response: <start> all depends on what kind of therapist they are . for most therapists , no , this is not usual . in my work with clients , their treatment goals are usually met or at least they have made enough progress to no longer need therapy by the . year mark . they may return to therapy for refreshers or later on to work on a separate issue , but the issue they came in with is generally resolved within that time period . . . . or . . . i refer them to someone else who i think may be able to help them in a different way than i can that may be a better fit . for therapists that are more psychodynamic relational , they tend to be focused on more long term therapy . it can be extremely helpful for some folks and not work for others . all in all , while a lot of therapists either forget to do this or do not make it part of their practice , we are ethically obligated to explain to clients how we practice , discuss what treatment looks like both explaining the frequency of visits , how long the sessions are , and an estimated time frame of how long therapy should take to resolve the presenting issue . this is all part of getting a client s consent to treatment . if you do not have this information , you do not really know what you are consenting to when you enter into therapy with any particular practitioner . <end>

title: <start> i have no idea if there is something wrong with me or not . <end>
response: <start> so , first , there is nothing wrong with you . i think too often we are told we are weird or wrong , but that just leads to feelings of shame . it sounds like you likely had some childhood trauma , alcoholics tend to do that to their family . avoidance is an indicator of trauma , as the feelings are so overwhelming . however , avoidance does not work long term , and the feelings always catch up to us eventually . know that when you are feeling sad , it is ok to feel sad . and when you feel happy , that is ok too . all of your feelings are normal , and this experience is not unusual . i would suggest talking to someone would be helpful , but understand that would be hard . it is the only real way to process what you have been through . some things you can do on your own is practice mindfulness be aware of your thoughts and feelings without judging them i am sure you could google all kinds of activities . practice relaxation skills , and consider yoga . yoga is being shown to be great for mental health . you can consider reading books or workbooks , and maybe start with something that is uplifting like a irene brown ted talk . she is amazing and has a bunch of books . i am not sure exactly what direction to send you in , but i think it is important to start increasing awareness of your feelings and just acknowledge them . they are not weird or wrong , they are just trying to tell you something . think of them like extra senses . your nose helps you smell , your eyes help you see , and your anger tells you something is bothering you . your joy tells you that something should continue and sadness is related to feelings of loss . they are just telling you something that you need to know . hope this helps <end>

title: <start> does race tend play a role in the therapy <end>
response: <start> therapist here . disclosure i am a cis white heterosexual male . . . . so yeah all the privilege in the world but i think i may be able to help give you some insight on some aspects here . feeling comfortable in the therapy setting is one of the most important aspects of whether it is going to be helpful or not . having to work through some of your anxiety regarding being accepted by someone who is not a person of color and may be cis het may be really helpful to you , so long as they are actually a good therapist and culturally competent . if they are , it could be really transformative for you . if they are not and trust me , plenty of therapists out there lacking cultural competence , especially around lgth issues it could be harmful . that being said , maybe you do not want to work through that stuff right now because you have bigger fish to fry and that is completely okay . any agency worth their salt looks to find therapists who are representative of the population they serve as plenty of folks feel more comfortable with someone they at least perceived of having a similar or shared experience . as a potential client , you get to decide what you are looking for in a therapist as far as demographics go . you do not necessarily get to decide if you go to a larger agency and get assigned something different despite your stating your preferences , but you do have the freedom to say alright , i am going to find somewhere else then . i work at an agency that exclusively serves the lgth population in my area . i have a ton of experience and passion for working with lgth folks . many do not want to work with me or are apprehensive given my demographics . that is understandable , but for those that have given it a shot , i would like to think we have done incredible work together . to answer your restated question race or any demographic differences between client and therapist has as much influence on a person s experience in therapy as both they decide to make it and their therapist s level of multi cultural competency . <end>

title: <start> girlfriend diagnosed with conversion disorder , symptoms include screaming uncontrollably , wants to go to psych ward . should she <end>
response: <start> she needs a full psych evaluation and a physical to rule out organic sources of her behavior . who diagnosed a conversion disorder this is a highly unusual diagnosis . uncontrollable screaming is not a symptom of a conversion disorder , but more the behavior of a histrionic personality disorder . i would admit her as an inpatient . there is much more going on here than meets the eye . <end>

response: <start> she had a neurological exam , blood tests , ct scan , and eeg , and they decided an mri was not worth doing because the ct and eeg were both normal . nothing showed up . i do not think she had a full psych evaluation but at the time she was seeing her psychiatrist , she had not experienced the screaming yet . she has been experiencing a myriad of other symptoms which suggest cd including vocal ticks , all out gibberish and inability to speak , very sensitive emotions , dissociative feelings , tremors in hands , jerking in legs and torso , eyes clenching shut , shoulders raising , arms and hands contorting like dystonia , and more . i am not sure what they could offer in terms of a full psych evaluation , but they diagnosed her with cd . other symptoms besides these which i could not find relating to cd and include speaking in different accents , laughing and crying uncontrollably , and very easily excitable emotions which affect her judgement . it is important to note that the majority of these symptoms are only present during an episode , except for the emotional anger and or intense sadness depression , which can last long after the preceding event . <end>
