title: <start> how honest can i be with a therapist what if what i am doing that is causing me tension is illegal or immoral would i be reported <end>
response: <start> the only things a therapist can report in the us at least are abuse and neglect of a minor or elder , or if you were to say you were going to kill someone , under tarasoft law , a therapist has a duty to warn that person . the other instance a therapist can break confidentiality is to get medical help if you are a serious risk to yourself , aka suicidal . robbed a bank nope , can not say anything . <end>

title: <start> can a therapist prescribe traveling or going out for the people who suffer from depression <end>
response: <start> there is no cure for depression . depression is a lifelong battle for many . there are some who only struggle with it situationally or exhibit symptoms of it during an adjustment disorder but many will tell you its lifelong for them . of course it can and will get better and treatment will depend on the therapist and the client . in my opinion i would work to build teach coping mechanisms for my clients that they will be able to use consistently and regularly . i am not sure that traveling is something that can be done regularly enough to help . this can vary on the client . if my client has a passion for traveling it may be time to explore a career change or hobby or something like that , but i am not there to advice them to go traveling . i am not there to give any advice , really . i am there to help them explore what about traveling is so good for them and how to find that in other aspects of life . is my client practicing enough self care how do they cope with stress others may disagree with me , but that is how i would approach your question . counseling is based on the wellness model , where psychiatry is more on the medical based model so i would personally refrain from saying i prescribed anything . again , this is just my perspective based on my guiding theory , schooling , and training . <end>

title: <start> honest question life as a young man <end>
response: <start> historical social norms you are right , relationships are heavily conjured up and empathised massively by society . i have always wondered apart from pro creation what is the obsession with having to be in a relationship it a considered the norm so much so that although i think it is got much better some people consider you weird if you are not in one . you do not need other people to be happy . you sound like you are lonely and think a of will fill this void . loneliness is just boredom . that is not a healthy reason to get into a relationship . a lot of people never stop and question what the reasons are for why they got into a relationship . most of the time it is just to fulfil a need so it is conditional . and it is very much like a trade , except we say i love you instead of i trade you . . . and when said person stops fulfilling that need the other person gets bored , seeks the need fulfilment elsewhere or leaves . you need to learn to be ok by yourself . enjoy doing things by yourself and if you are not willing to do all the said adult things you mentioned then you need to focus on that too . you need to be your best possible version to meet someone who can match that for you so that you can have a great relationship . <end>

response: <start> i would go to a doctor and figure out if it is a sudden and spontaneous allergy to cotton . it might be a rash skin irritation that comes from the fabric , cotton , being rubbed on your body too much . i would definitely take pictures the next time it happens and see if there is any irritation or rash where the fabric once was . edit i know that i kind of have the same sort of reaction with a pen i have , the feeling of it and the sound it makes when i take the cap off sometimes bothers me and sometimes does not . i also always rip off my shoes when i get home , but that might because i hate wearing shoes . it is almost like my feet hurt and get hot when i wear my shoes anywhere i do not have to wear them . i also hate socks . i do not have the same thing you do , just get it checked out and i would not use cod oil quite yet until you know what it is . it could because further irritation . <end>

title: <start> i do not know how to open up <end>
response: <start> wait a minute now . this is not r alanin . my first thought reading through this was pufftn . he is got a month old and he is tired and wants alone time . you have not met clingy yet , my friend . wait ll you have a whiny two year old . i totally get what you are saying , and i have been married for years and raised kids , so i have some experience here . i am not putting the blame on you . absolutely , it is on your wife to make friends and develop interests , but hear me when i say , your wife just spent months pregnant , giving birth is pretty traumatic , and you have got the hormone cocktail going on . she is likely sleep deprived , her body has probably changed , she is probably unsure of herself , and second guessing everything she is doing for that baby , on top of trying to care for her own body that is healing . put all that on top of being lonely and whatever issues there actually were to start with . if this is her first baby , she probably will not be able to see her own behavior attitude until she is passed this and can look back on it . of course , i am just speaking generally here . she could have all of this , none of this or any combo in between . now explain to me why we are encouraging the man that works outside of the house all day away from his wife and newborn to advocate for time alone . why are not we encouraging him to send his wife out for literally anything . . . exercise , shopping , manicure , just out into the sunlight with a clean shirt and no diaper bag . i like my alone time , too i feel you , but suck it up . this is adusting and you signed up for it . too late to change your mind , just because it is hard . what she is doing is hard , too , and she probably can not wait for you to get home . pushing her away right now is going to make her feel unattractive . you know how you always hear people say marriage is hard this is the hard part . it will get better , but if the plan is for her to be a sham , your job right now , is to support your family and support your wife by making sure she is taking care of herself , and mentally and physically in a good place so she does a good job taking care of the baby . otherwise , you are going to have a whole new set of problems . what you want does not matter anymore , it is whatever has to be done to take care of that baby . besides , you will be home alone with the baby while the wife is out , right <end>

title: <start> how to help a depressed person to make therapy appointments <end>
response: <start> you can not force anyone to go to therapy . even if you would think it would help , therapy is not some panacea but a team effort between client and therapist . now the one exception is if they were to try to harm themselves via suicide . than you could ensure they are put in an inpatient center . however other than that , you need to accept that these people are not going . all you can do is watch unfortunately . at least your bf is on his meds . <end>

title: <start> remembering things post session <end>
response: <start> it sounds like you have a pretty good idea of what might be helpful writing more and it could be good to brainstorm with your therapist on why it is hard and what might help . one thing that i think is super helpful for a lot of people including myself , is writing out a story about the relationship and the breakup . you just word vomit and write everything out as if you were explaining it to someone you trusted totally , but who did not know you or your partner . a lot of times this alone is enough to have an impact on making our feelings and abstract thoughts more concrete however it can also be helpful to edit it . some might find it helpful to edit it down to a one page summary they keep on their phone , so in times of confusion they can reread their own truth . sometimes , it can be helpful to take the story to therapy , and talk about what points feels foggy or have a particular negative feelings attached . <end>

title: <start> why am i overstaring <end>
response: <start> talking about things is helpful . that is one of the reasons people go to therapy . boundaries are important in friendships though . if you are not very close to someone , telling about your mental health issues or your struggles is going to be off putting . it is not so different than if you were to start talking about your sex life with someone you just met . with people you are close to , it should be okay , but even with these folks , if the majority of your conversations with them center around your mental health issues , especially if you are frequently always seeking support from the same folks , it could wear them out and they may not stick around very long . once again , a good reason why many folks go to see a therapist . it is our job to listen , help you process , and figure out ways to overcome these difficulties . we may care about you , but we are not your friends . for some folks , therapy can be a dumping ground so that they can fulfill their need to talk about it without sacrificing their friendships , at least early on until they have gotten a better handle on things . <end>

title: <start> how to effectively take a mental health day <end>
response: <start> i would taking the day to relax and set things up for your future self . like make appointments with therapist and or psychiatrists , clean the house or just your room , do laundry , find and try some new coping skills , and just relax . play some video games , watch tv , whatever you enjoy . i personally do not think spending the entire day playing games is the best use of a mental health day , like you should get a couple things done , but games are a big part of it <end>

title: <start> blame game <end>
response: <start> effective listening and observing is essential when communicating and especially so with the person you are dating . a big chunk of our communication is non verbal . it is in the body language or tone of speech . is the other person looking down , mumbling , hugging themselves this might indicate discomfort , fear , feeling unsafe . noting your own nonverbal communication can help you understand how she might perceive the communication . if there is no eye contact , nodding while the other is speaking , or frequent checking of the cell phone , the other person might interpret it as you do not care . communication is ideally two way . you listen and receive the information she is sending you . you interpret , consider being in her shoes , then respond , with a goal in mind . is the goal reconciling the argument and understanding eachother more or winning the argument without understanding eachother blaming others is a defense mechanism . to overcome it , taking responsibility for your wrongs and accountability can go along way . <end>

title: <start> talking to a therapist about amphetamines as a young adult . <end>
response: <start> in most localities , therapists psychotherapists with a masters degree , psychologists with a phd do not prescribe medication . usually it is a medical doctor or psychiatrist medical doctor focusing on mental health who would prescribe meds . the doctor will likely want to confirm the diagnosis since you are coming in with no proof , asking for drugs . they may just ask you a ton or questions or may have you tested again . try to see if you can request your medical records . if you took the drug without a prescription , it may not be wise to bring that up . be honest if they ask , but if you tell them you want a specific medication , tell them you have taken it recreationally , and do not have any proof that you need it , then you might appear to the doctor to be drug seeking . <end>

title: <start> how do i deal with the symptoms of invalidation fro . childhood as an adult <end>
response: <start> i do not have any articles to share but , for me , my therapist will break out the traditional affirmations when i struggle with this . you have to manually build new neural pathways until your brain can do it on its own . it is like strengthening a weak muscle . you are not going to be able to do a ton of reps or a heavy lift the first time you try . you have to start small and practice a lot and the muscle will become stronger in time . sometimes it helps me to keep these in a note in my phone and sometimes i just say them out loud . you deserve to be happy . you deserve treatment . your problems are big enough . you are worth it . you are amazing . you can trust yourself . you deserve a break . you deserve love . you are allowed to ask for things and you deserve to feel supported . you did not deserve these bad things that happened to you . the people who hurt you are not good for you and you deserve to take care of yourself . things like that . i keep the note in my phone in the second person but sometimes when i am talking out loud i use i instead of you . it just depends on what i am feeling . i hope this helps at least a tiny bit . it feels really cookie at first but with time that muscle will get stronger , your neural pathways will become more myelinated , and it will come more naturally . <end>

title: <start> when dealing with rumination due to grieving , does avoidance work as a coping strategy <end>
response: <start> avoidance is a popular coping strategy , but the least effective . there is a metaphor i like to use with clients that are avoidant that i learned from someone much smarter than myself i you fell on glass , and had glass embedded in your knee , you have options . you can ignore it , and pretend it never happened . the skin may heal over , and the glass will hurt you every time it is triggered . or , you can take a brush , and gently wipe out the glass . this will hurt , like removing splinters . the pain gets worse , but then when the glass is all gone , you can put ointment and a bandage and let it heal . you will still have the scars , but it will not hurt anymore . the point is , no , avoidance will never solve the problem . it will always be there , and sneak up on you with painful memories . instead , it is better to process the loss , feel the feelings , and when you are ready , take a step back and acknowledge the hard work you did . when looking back , you will remember the person , but it will not hurt , at least not the same . and you will be able to smile at the times you had together . radical acceptance can be a really difficult task , and there are lots of strategies . it might be best to talk with a professional to help you manage <end>

title: <start> is it add or trauma <end>
response: <start> it can be difficult for clinicians to rule out trauma . the absence of his father could certainly have been processed as trauma trauma is relative , and children with trauma backgrounds tend to fit the add checklists and can be diagnosed with add . both can impact executive functioning which is the part of the brain that affects impulses , mood and behavioral regulation , and organization planning . a neuropsychologist evaluation could be helpful in deciphering this . those evaluations can be expensive , so if your insurance will not cover it , a good place to start could be requesting an evaluation by the school psychologist . i think you also could consider what differences there would be in support if it were diagnosis over the other definitely necessary if you are ever considering the medication route add meds are really over prescribed , although they do not usually medicate children that young . i would also advocate for social emotional support at school either way , and possibly interventions and supports to focus on supporting the organizational piece in the classroom . outside therapy can also be a helpful outlet either way , especially if there is a history he may benefit from processing through . <end>

title: <start> why do i feel like someone is controlling me <end>
response: <start> it sounds like you are in crisis and you should seek out mental health help as soon as possible . reach out to an adult you trust a teacher , a school counselor , a coach and tell them that you have tried to harm yourself and are still trying to harm yourself and that you need help to ensure your safety . your symptoms sound like some type of psychosis . it is not uncommon for people to feel like they are being controlled or being forced to do bad things . feeling like that must be really scary and i am so proud of you for reaching out and asking for help . medication and therapy can help what you are experiencing . there are good adults who will help you . please tell someone in your life what is going on so they can get you the services you need . <end>

title: <start> can i tell a therapist this asking for a friend <end>
response: <start> therapists are generally mandated reporters , so if someone disclosed abuse to us , we are required to report it . that was likely in your intake paperwork or she mentioned it in your first session . therapists take confidentiality very seriously except when it comes to abuse disclosures or if you are a risk of harm to yourself or others , like if you told your therapist you were going to go home and kill yourself . personally , if a client told me they were purposely starving themselves with the intention to die of starvation , that would be different than the intention of losing weight . i would encourage you to tell your mom and offer support or offer for you to tell her about it in session , but i do not think i would just outright report it unless you were at immediate risk of harm to yourself . however , i work in foster care , so our rules about disclosing are a little different than a therapist in private practice , so you may have to take my words with a grain of salt . edit this is coming as a human being and not as a therapist . your mom quilting you for talking to your therapist instead of her is not cool . i do not know your situation , but it is common for abusive parents to say things like how could you talk to someone else about our family matters with an emphasis on keeping all your shit within the family . if you do not let anyone in , no one can see how bad things are . i am not suggesting that is what your mom is doing , but it is a good thing to keep in mind for the future . <end>

title: <start> are full blown hallucinations where you lose complete touch with reality a real thing i have a friend who claims they get these but i am weary . <end>
response: <start> as someone who has worked with plenty of folks with psychotic disorders , this type of thing does exist , but is pretty rare . for most folks with severe schizophrenia , auditory hallucinations are the most common along with a set a strange delusions ie . i am actually an angel sent from god , the government is broadcasting signals to me , etc . . vivid visual hallucinations are extremely rare unless there is also some drug use involved . for the most part , schizophrenia does not really hit folks until late teens early adulthood . for men , generally late teens early s . for women it is generally in early to mid s . what your friend is describing sounds like it could either be an overactive imagination or some type of flashback or dissociative episode that happens to folks who have experienced some trauma in their lives . i can not will not give any type of diagnosis or anything like that based off of a reedit post , but these types of things are possible , though fairly rare . <end>

title: <start> what is a good example of projection <end>
response: <start> disclaimer not a professional therapist projection can manifest in a number of ways , but its usually at least somewhat linked to our own personal insecurities and is commonly used as a defense mechanism . you have probably heard some variation of the phrase the things we dislike most about others are the things we dislike most about ourselves . that is a form of projection . a good example of this is a person who struggles with or who has struggled with their weight resenting or judging other overweight people . the individual in question might assign labels like lazy or slob , which are character assessments based not on reality , but on personally held biases . another form of projection is when a person makes assumptions about someone s thoughts , feelings , or motivations based on their own thoughts feelings motivations . if an individual is insecure about their public speaking ability , after giving a perfectly adequate talk , they might say something like oh my god , i bombed that presentation . everyone must think i am so stupid . this individual s statement is not an assessment of an objective reality , but rather a projection of their own insecurity onto the audience . x b from personal experience i once dated a woman who admitted to me that she had cheated on of her ex boyfriends . the entire time we were together , she was unusually controlling and suspicious . if i had to work late , she would freak out and once even asked me to send her a picture of my desk as proof that i was in the office . this was in spite of the fact that i had never given her any reason to suspect me of infidelity and had , in fact , never cheated on anyone in my life . she was projecting her own thoughts of infidelity on me as a self defense mechanism . we all know that everyone is the hero of their own story but some people , instead of acknowledging their flaws , seek to shift the blame to those around them in order to preserve an idealized version of their identity . <end>

title: <start> how to deal with post facts , gaslighting , conspiracy theories <end>

title: <start> is it ethical for a therapist to refuse my call during a paid for session <end>
response: <start> a few things here , but first no , there was nothing unethical of what your therapist did . i know that is not the answer you are looking for but phone therapy is not an obligation or even recommended . i am sure you are thinking that is my normal scheduled session so that time is mine , i know my therapist is not doing anything but that is really not how it works and is also not fair . talking on the phone is in no way or form an adequate replacement for a therapy session . in regards to the other comment , the likelihood of the fee being more than the session is highly unlikely , and would not be a typical motivator . in fact there are more ethical issues with wanting to discuss your suicidal ideation on the phone , which is probably the primary reason why your therapist avoided discussing this on the phone in the first place . this does not even include all the things that are missed over the phone body language , facial expressions , and overall physical cues that therapists are supposed to notice and analyze . given your suicidal ideation with the unknown fact if your state is a mandatory reporting state , i am going to assume it is . say you were feeling a significant level of suicidal ideation and had a plan , access and overall high level of intent . once you admit that to your therapist , the laws protecting confidentiality go out the window and you could be emergency petitioned into a hospital to protect yourself or have an emergency psychiatric evaluation . now if this occurs in person this is a fairly simple thing to do . cops are called , you two wait and then you are escorted to the hospital and the hospital takes over from there . but now let us say you are on the phone with your therapist . he she has no ability to know where you are , and is also now ethically responsible for your well being and safety . if you are halfway across the state , or somewhere inaccessible , that makes it significantly more difficult to handle the situation to a degree that would be considered appropriate by our boards standards . if it was a truly exceptional situation and you needed to see your therapist , the best thing to do is to try to schedule a make up session and verbalize the importance . either later in the day or the next day . if it was so urgent that you needed to talk to your therapist as soon as possible , that would also indicate that a crisis line or a call would also be sufficient . i am unsure if your therapist indicated these other options to you , but it is good for you to know your other available options . if you do continue therapy with this therapist i would bring up this issue in the next session . if you do not trust your therapist fully , that damages the therapy process as you will not feel the necessary transparency and desire for honesty to help your overall presenting concerns . <end>

title: <start> weird story therapist and conflicted <end>
response: <start> one thing to be certain is that you should never really expect to get a whole lot or feel fixed after one therapy session . therapist is process that can take time . first sessions are generally focused on allowing the clinician to get to know you a little bit and allowing you to get to know them . every therapist works differently , some share anecdotes and personal experiences in order to help teach something or let you get to know them and others will not talk about themselves at all . i generally tell folks to give it three sessions working with a therapist . if you feel like there is a connection and they may be able to help you , great , if not , move on and immediately look for a new therapist . if cost a big concern , you may want to just move on now , but also make sure that you realize for even the briefest of therapies to be effective , it is likely you are going to need to go to weekly sessions for a good while for it to be effective . make sure you are able to budget for this as you do not want to blow a bunch of money on or sessions and have to drop out due to finances . then you will be out that money and likely will not see any substantial results . being in the you . s . i do not know much about this human givens approach as it seems pretty uk centric , new , and not very well established . the little bit of internet diving i did , it does not seem like it is an evidenced based practice or that there is much research on it . i would be somewhat wary of practitioners pushing something like this . here s the thing . every therapist has a framework that they prefer to work from , but many therapists are eclectic and can use various different modalities in their treatment . if what your therapist is doing is not working for you , tell them . let them know what aspects of their working with you helps you and which does not . many will be able and willing to adjust . for those that can not or will not , then it is time to seek a different therapist . <end>

response: <start> i believe that what you are asking would be very difficult to determine over a reedit post . . . but i will try anyways . a persons personal experiences and belief systems are a complicated and nuanced jumble that helps make someone who they are . i know that may not be especially helpful in this moment , but it could be helpful moving forward . my favorite say to the kids i work with is how you feel is real , but it may not be true . now , that is not to say you are somehow dishonest . all that statement is meant to do is to be a way to check things in with yourself by slowing down your thoughts and feelings . from the little you have said , how you feel is real , and right now , maybe the battle you are fighting is trying to understand if it is true or not and then trying to convince your therapist the same . you are the expert on you . if you say you are out of sorts and something is wrong , then it is likely true . the struggle then becomes agreeing on a name . instead , maybe it would be more beneficial in the short term to collectively focus on interventions that can improve your general mood or feeling , and more importantly , assure your safety . <end>

title: <start> from a professional standpoint is it better to move away from triggers <end>
response: <start> this is a great question . creating distance or cutoff from something triggering people or place is evidence of a problem , fixes a problem , and perpetuates the same problem . i , as a therapist , am of two minds about it moving away to not have to see the triggers is likely to make things easier making things easier does not mean things are better or healed , it allows the painful feelings to not be felt , rather than resolved . maybe there is a middle ground , of avoiding the playground until your wife has improved enough that she can confront and deal with some of the really difficult things that are brought up by the triggers . ultimately , i am of the belief we all need to face our fears and our triggers and it is through that we are able to find healing . however , there are valid reasons to not do this . <end>

title: <start> i am scared to go to therapy . <end>
response: <start> i understand starting therapy can be very stressful , especially because you are starting to work on yourself , and working on yourself means making yourself vulnerable , and by definition that is one of the hardest things to do . i got to ask you what do you mean by or so i have been told if you do not know from where to start or if you find yourself confused , try writing down on a piece of paper the top things you would like to work on or the top things that are bothering you . it may help with consolidating your thoughts . concerning antidepressants , they are not a wonder pill that you take and immediately feel better . they usually need a couple of weeks or longer to start working and in the beginning there is a good chance you will feel a bit more depressed , but have no fear because this is completely normal . but also concerning pharmacotherapy , medication is not always needed , sometimes you can work through things by just talking with your therapist . medication is a thing he will prescribe if he or she thinks it is needed . i see you wrote this post weeks ago and i hope this answer helps , but most of all i hope you started going . good luck and take care <end>

title: <start> not sure if this belongs here . . . but i need help <end>
response: <start> oddly , it sounds like you are already doing the necessary compartmentalization if you are holding it together in sessions . how you respond after sessions is a good indicator that supervision and perhaps your own therapy are necessary . getting awareness of your own stuff , what it means to you , and how you choose to respond , is at the heart of how to handle the day to day stress of your clients stuff . and what a wonderful opportunity in grad school to run into this type of situation now , rather than in the wild . gaining awareness of your stuff and how it comes up in therapy is not the same thing as losing your ability to feel for others . while they warn that empathy burnout is a thing , trust me , it is not going to happen if you learn more about your own reactions . quite the opposite , imo . <end>

title: <start> can a person self diagnose themself by searching the dam <end>
response: <start> not a therapist self diagnoses are extremely risky and dangerous . we are often very biased to the stories of our own lives . and in most cases , we are the worst critics of our own stories because of these biases . we can easily be convinced that we know everything there is to know about ourselves . we see ourselves act in the real world , who could know me better than myself but sometimes , we need a mirror to reflect on events that happen , in a clear manner . clinicians are those mirrors , and in most cases pretty pristine ones at that . there is no real way of diagnosing yourself of anything other than seeing a professional that deals with suspected diagnoses . if you do feel like there is something big in your life you feel you would like to understand more , but may not be able to on your own , reach out to a therapist . it is totally worth having a neutral party to help talk through it with . one thing i will suggest however that you can implement on your own , to bring clarity , and an introspective view on your life , is having a journal . taking minutes a day to just be completely honest with yourself about what you feel , what is on your mind , why you think you feel like this , and why this is on your mind . all of this will definitely bring more insight into your life , and what you go through everyday . self honesty is a vastly underrated form of taking steps toward understanding yourself and others more clearly . i hope this helps <end>

title: <start> confidentiality medical history <end>
response: <start> therapy is generally confidential but there are some instances where confidentiality can be broken when you are a danger to yourself or others , if there is a child in danger , etc . the therapist you work with should make these situations clear from the start if they do not , ask them . generally therapists write brief notes about each session which they keep secure and do not share with anyone unless they have to break confidentiality . if you are paying for sessions with insurance , there may be some information that is shared with the insurance company diagnosis , treatment plan , etc it varies by jurisdiction , ask what will be shared ahead of time or consider paying out of pocket . you can ask your therapist not to diagnose you or not to share their diagnosis with you in some jurisdictions a psychotherapist cannot diagnose a client it has to be done by a doctor or psychologist . if you are just looking for a non judgemental person to talk to without any requirements for change , consider a psychodynamic psychotherapist they have no expectation for you to commit to change . that is the general answer to your questions , the specifics depend on your location country , state province , etc . <end>

title: <start> question about ethics <end>
response: <start> i kind of have two minds about your question , so i am going to try to explain my thought process a little bit . first of all , i would say it would unethical for a therapist you have not seen in the past two years to share a diagnosis , or anything really with your wife after the fact like that . the waters are a little more muddy when it comes to couples therapy , but even then , she was your therapist as well as your wife s , and discussing something about you like that could likely be seen as a breach of your confidentiality . that being said , i wonder how that conversation between the wife and therapist actually went . odds are , she was sharing quite a few negative situations and complaints about you , that may have met the criteria for narcissistic tendencies , and who knows what the therapist said in response to that . of course that is not a real diagnosis , and i am pretty sure everybody has narcissistic tendencies at some point . have you ever lacked empathy been arrogant haughty maybe somebody perceives you as entitled . maybe they believe that you are exploitive . these are all characteristics of a narcissistic person , but an actual diagnosis requires it to be a pervasive pattern . you are not wrong for denying that you are a narcissist . you are right , anybody who is not a narcissist who was accused of being a narcissist would also deny that . just because an actual narcissist would also deny being a narcissist does not prove anything . as to what you should do , personally , i probably would not do anything but continue to have discussions with my wife about what it means to her that she thought i was narcissist . or what it say about her . if she truly thinks you are a narcissistic person who has no empathy for anybody , why would she want to be in a relationship with that person . it might be helpful to have more marriage counseling to help resolve those issues . if you really wanted to , i am sure you could find a psychologist who would also be able to put you through some amount of questioning and testing and come up with an official diagnosis . although i probably would not go that far . as for the therapist , there really are three options . one , do nothing . two , contact the therapist and ask her about what she told your wife . three , if you really think it is an issue , you could contact her professional licensing or ethics board , and make a complaint . but , without knowing what therapist actually said , versus what your wife has incorrectly interpreted or told you about that conversation , that might not go very far . <end>

title: <start> my sister is asking me for a list of good bad sides of her character . should i help her <end>
response: <start> what is the therapist thinking by suggesting something like this two things that come to mind . a client with depression may not accurately know their positive qualities due to their illness and would be surprised to see their positive traits as listed by someone else . . in general , when people share their authentic thoughts and feelings with each other , even when there are negative traits being noted , then the relationship develops in ways that help both sides feel better , more accepted , and more real . so even if you have significant criticisms of your sister , would not you like her to know so she can work on those traits note this is my thoughts . not every therapist thinks the same . <end>

title: <start> am i mentally ill or is it just the people around me is everyone who shows symptoms of a mental disorder ill what does mental illness mean <end>
response: <start> not a therapist but , you might not be bothered by your described characteristics , however your family is and that is something worth considering . if enough people in your life say that there is something off about you , chances are , they are right . i think it would be in your best interest to open a line of honest communication between you and your family . honesty can go a very long way , and i am sure if you give your family a chance they might be more open to helping you answer the questions about mental illness , you came here to ask . as a disclaimer therapists are here to assist you with setting positive , healthy and mindful goals for yourself . also to help facilitate these goals as they are executed in your life . they give you the tools required , in order to achieve what you discover to really want need at that time . going through therapy can be a useful opportunity to begin understanding yourself , as well as those around you a lot more clearly . give it a shot , the most you will lose is a few hours of your time , but the potential benefits vastly outweigh that sacrifice . good luck to you <end>

title: <start> how much to tell a therapist <end>
response: <start> in my practice , i usually safety plan for passive suicidal ideation and only resort to crisis unit hospitalization if the ideation is active . telling me you want to go to sleep and not wake up is a lot different than telling me you are going to go home and overdose . there are exceptions to the rules and it really depends on the session context and so many other factors i would encourage you to be open and honest with your therapist , so i would just ask her what she would do if you expressed suicidal ideation . it is a fairly obvious question but it can come up naturally in your first session when she reviews confidentiality practices with you . <end>

title: <start> is there ever a time where not blaming other s do not work <end>
response: <start> i am not a therapist but your question has a cultural components so i thought id add my cents . the societal axiom which atomized us into individuals where most of our interactions are defined by the flow of capital , is called neoliberalism . it is a rather new phenomena , the purpose , ostensibly , was to empower capital , cripple labor and sustain an empire . as you may have noticed , this part of history has run its course and new narratives will be available within our lifetime . your question is one of cultural narrative , so the answer is yes and no , depending on which narrative is the most materially , psychologically and socially helpful . currently that is to be the rugged individual , separate , rational and given total agency over their lives . if others do react well to you , you are not branding yourself correctly , not making the right choices or are otherwise deficient . or perhaps , you were born into a society where your default economic , social and biological condition were not determined by you . nor did you spread the desolation and isolation which is fueling both fascist and leftist movements around the world . look at the health outcomes in so called blue zones and you will see that the one of the most accurate predictors of health is the strength of the communities in those areas . use what helps you most . i would caution against blame simply because it is a dis empowering feeling but i would encourage a critical analysis of the world around you which can provide some context for how and where you deviate . then you can make the moral decisions which follow . as krishnamurti said it is no great accomplishment to be well adjusted to a profoundly sick society x b x b x b <end>

response: <start> you make perfect sense to me . words definitely have different connotations for different people . when i hear blame i think of feelings like shame , guilt or deficiency . however , i think we may be discussing what i understand as responsibility and in that context , i could not have put it better than you did in your last paragraph . i do think taking personal responsibility is very healthy and practical . as to blue zones http www . bluestones . com live longer better section these are parts of the world such as okinawa japan where have longer , healthier lives and report that they are happier with communal relationships than , for example , much of the us . i do not think i am qualified to explain all the nuances involved with the study of blue zones . the concept came from dan boettner who has written a book http www . amazon . com blue zones lessons living longest dp describing his research conclusions . there is also his ted talk http www . couture . com watch v ff yimmvku if you do not want to get and read a whole book . as to your final question , that would be a matter of personality . for example , i regard a sense of control as illusory and enjoy the serenity in surrender . i still go to the gym , study hard , work hard , try to be a good friend but reject the myth of meritocracy . however , other people i know feel very empowered by a sense of control and enjoy projecting it . <end>

title: <start> how does sexual trauma experienced in adolescence affect adult men <end>
response: <start> whoa cool question i think society does play an important role in how people handle traumatic events , so i wonder what a beating meant in ancient greece versus now . if beatings from parents were more common at that time , perhaps that would make the incident less likely to be outright traumatic in the sense of causing flashbacks and apprehension , but perhaps more subtly showing up as a great deal of shame note that this is all highly speculative . i have never lived in a society where beatings were normalized . but let us say for the sake of your story that my speculation is accurate . he would be carrying around all this shame , and his perception of his female partners already shaded by ancient greek attitudes towards women would be to consider their role in sex shameful so far that is in line with your madonna whore theory . so he might be irritated in general by his partner because she literally embodies the shameful part of sex . but , people who have a deep seated shame surrounding sex often process that into a kink . it is possible that your main character could develop a fetish for oral sex . perhaps his way of processing his initial shame and other cultural baggage around it is to feel ridiculously turned on by it and possibly to ask for additional pleasure and pain dynamics to be introduced , such as having his partner restrain him so that he can not resist this shameful act , spankings and other s m type punishment . he may also develop a fetish for being the shameful one performing oral sex on his female partner . . . . suffice it to say your scenario brings up lots of creative possibilities where your character might be conflicted and unsure if he can love his partner for being so shameful , or if he might find a deep and abiding love for her for being so kind and understanding , and for allowing him to do these shameful acts . he might truly appreciate his partner because he is able to be his true self and drop his masculine persona . as for his other relationships . . . it sounds like he would have to hide his past and if you choose to go in the direction of kinks as i have suggested , then he would have to hide his kinks from them too . his friendships would be good , but there would always be an element of holding certain things back . think of it sort of like being in the closet . i had friends who were in a poly relationship , and before they disclosed the true nature of their relationship to us we were definitely close . however , our relationship bonded and became so much closer not to mention more complicated when they told us their secret . please know that his male friendships would be fulfilling , but incomplete . and for those he let us in behind the mask , perhaps he might have a friend who let us it slip that he enjoys something shameful too , and he can share his secret with this friend , those friendships are likely to become very emotionally intimate . relationships with children it depends on the child s personality to be sure . boys i anticipate he would be trying to get them to be faultlessly male , while having the inner conflict of not living that standard himself . perhaps there is emotional intimacy possible there if his child thinks dad is faultlessly male , but dad reveals he is not faultlessly male to his son . that would probably bond them together in a way that is difficult to describe . even today men struggle to be vulnerable . but when one of us manages to let some cracks in the wall show , it is sort of like handing someone a knife with the understanding that they can stab you in the back at any time , but also knowing they will not . girls i imagine he would be transmitting a lot of negative attitudes about women to his daughters , perhaps by way of showing he cares by explaining to them how they are inherently flawed , and how they can avoid some of the worst parts of their nature . he would probably think he was coming from a place of love while doing some damage . since i am proposing a character arc for your character of learning to accept his own femininity more , then perhaps the relationship with his daughter would be to stop policing her so much and just love her for who she is <end>

response: <start> thank you so much for writing such a detailed , well thought out answer you have been tremendously helpful , i really can not thank you enough . i think in my character s case , the beating happens when the character is caught in the act , and is severe enough to require medical attention the fact that his mentor did not protect him and abandoned him after combined with the extreme boundary violation of his father interrupting such a sexually charged event with overkill brutality would , i think , create a profound break in his ability to love himself and trust others . your point about developing a kink to safely explore taboo desires makes so much sense but when one of us manages to let some cracks in the wall show , it is sort of like handing someone a knife with the understanding that they can stab you in the back at any time , but also knowing they will not . shew masculinity is such a minefield . my heart breaks for little boys , it really does . thank you for these insights , they have really helped . x b <end>

title: <start> lack of empathy <end>
response: <start> it is hard to say for sure with limited information but yes trauma can effect empathy , particularly emotional empathy . emotional empathy is where you feel other people s feelings , cognitive empathy is more like perspective taking where you know what someone else is feeling . trauma can effect this in many ways , one way is that the empathy never develops as a child , another is when a person represses memories as a protective coping strategy but this creates an emotional barrier so they do not feel emotions strongly and it can impair their empathy . studies have shown that individuals with ptsd can show lower empathic resonance . what are your thought on this cognitive empathy is learned so you can develop this improve it , emotional empathy can grow depending on the because of its impairment <end>

response: <start> hey thanks for responding first of all . . also i might say that my empathy for other people is very picky if that makes sense i only feel for people i truly care about which only happens once in a full moon also something that has to do with me not trusting people and assuming people do not actually care for me but just think they do to not think of themselves as bad people if that makes sense i have been noticing that most of my lack of empathy is cognitive and just understanding people in general and my assumptions about people before i meet them because of pretty bad past experience . i have add and have taken tests on the internet for being a hip hyper sensitive person and am not really sure anymore wether i lack empathy because of my past abuse or wether i am just a hurt over sensitive individual that is scared to care about other people . i also have been reading fiction books with the idea to learn from it which i feel like has somewhat increased my cognitive empathy by putting myself in other people s shoes and reflecting back on what i have just read and try my hardest to understand the person more instead of viewing them as evil stupid for their decisions . also there have been instances in my life where i can remember crying for people i have never met when i was about years old and going through a rough time in my life myself i would google images videos articles about syrian children and cry in front on my computer because i wanted to help them and felt for them and wanted to take action to change their lives or save them . it probably sounds weird but i did it and there have been more times in my life where i would do that things that like that make me think that i do not lack empathy , or that it is more something i choose to have . when my grandma went to the hospital and me and her had lighted a lot before that i did not seem to care that much and was kind of happy that she was gone and more interested in what i would gain from it financially if she died but after maybe a few hours after dancing and not caring i kind of started caring . same happened with my grandpa , even though he actually died x b p . s sorry if this was too long , i just want to know what you think <end>

response: <start> i really admire the work you are doing here to grow and be better , it takes a lot of strength and it sounds like you are really searching for ways to change your attitudes and learn how to empathise . no one is perfect and we all should look at ourselves and see where we need to improve every so often . it sounds like you maybe numb your feelings as a defence mechanism you assume people do not care and will hurt you let you down so you block of your feelings so you do not get hurt . the brain thinks it is helping you here but as we can see it is actually detrimental to your relationships and ability to have positive interactions with others . when you say you lack cognitive empathy because you struggle to understand people is this due to your trauma you feel people are like those who hurt you this could be projection if the trauma is not addressed we can project our feelings towards those that hurt us onto others . projection can also be when we unconsciously protect ourselves by denying the existence of something within ourselves and attribute it to others . how does your add effect you you did say you have empathy occasionally with people you truly care for , what does that feel like i am not really sure anymore whether i lack empathy because of my past abuse or whether i am just a hurt over sensitive individual that is scared to care about other people . i felt this was quite powerful , and it could be a bit of both to care about others and let yourself have feelings for them is to allow yourself to be vulnerable it is through vulnerability that we form true connections but vulnerability can feel really scary after a bad experience . what you said about reading is a great step towards improving your cognitive empathy it sounds like you are studying them like a text so you can learn and understand , that is great you could continue this with different characters and personalities , such as those you might encounter girl . in your last paragraph you explain moments of genuine emotional empathy as if you caught feelings , and that a part of you was devested by the unnecessary pain these individuals went through , perhaps you could relate to them in some way . the syrian children were safer for you than your grandparents because you did not have a personal relationship with them . it could have been a defence to not care or think of what you would gain a positive even but your suppressed feelings began to push through . remember just because you are not feeling certain things does not mean the feeling is not there , often we are pushing it down and denying it is existence . sorry for the late reply , i wanted to read through what you said properly and take time to reply and this is the first chance i have had . if you would rather chat about this privately feel free to pm me <end>

title: <start> is distraction healthy or unhealthy coping <end>
response: <start> oddly complex question . it is usually healthy . think of it sort of like masturbation . for the most part it is healthy , but it is possible to do it too much , and for your relationships and responsibilities to suffer if you are spending too much time doing it . that is a simplistic answer . there is more nuance than that . <end>

title: <start> oddly complex question . it is usually healthy . think of it sort of like masturbation . for the most part it is healthy , but it is possible to do it too much , and for your relationships and responsibilities to suffer if you are spending too much time doing it . that is a simplistic answer . there is more nuance than that . <end>

response: <start> when you have to consistently distract yourself from the same thoughts and feelings over and over again , that is a good sign that you are not processing those thoughts and feelings . <end>

response: <start> does not distraction entail not processing the thoughts and feelings , though i thought the point of distraction is to not dwell on distressing thoughts by replacing them with something else . so , if processing is necessary if i understand you correctly how can you distract in a healthy way <end>

response: <start> that is why this is a tricky question sometimes we will assign clients to come up with distractions because the thoughts they are having are just being dwelled on . for example , suicidal ideation . you would still have to address the underlying issues that because you to feel suicidal , but sometimes you just need something to get you to stop dwelling on on suicide because it is basically a pity party . on the other hand , sometimes distractions are the problem . like , if you are failing out of school , but instead of dealing with that you are writing a d d campaign . <end>

title: <start> how can i stop allowing rejection from lost jobs and workers make me miserable <end>
response: <start> sounds like you are ready to change this is wonderful i would suggest a few things . figure out what you are actually good at . not necessarily what you like , or want to do , or what is lucrative , but what you have skills in . begin to investigate jobs that would play to those strengths instead of playing to your resume . you may have to take another shit job just to pay the bills , but it is easier to work a shit job if you are in school to change careers which is something i have personal experience doing . i used to think that my ability to deal with all sorts of people in all sorts of moods was a death sentence to spend the rest of my days in dead end customer service roles . i was wrong . . start communicating with local therapists email , phone , whatever , and see if someone in your area has some experience helping someone discern career choices , and general workplace difficulty . i think you would do well in therapy right now because you sound like you are tired of your old thinking patterns . you might also ask the therapists in your area if any of them have ever personally been fired or had to change careers before getting into their current line of work . someone like that could be a good role model of sorts and i know many therapists come to the field later in life like this one . . i dunno . a list just does not feel like a list with only two items , so here s rufus thomas singing my current theme song http youth . be b tp perdu which probably will not help you very much , but it sure is funky . <end>

title: <start> fear of being healthy . <end>
response: <start> i could not tell you , specifically , what it is about being healthy that you are afraid of , but i did want to say that i do not find it so strange that it would be scary to consider making these changes . is it counter intuitive sure , but so is a lot of human behavior . you have presumably lived in your current state of health for a long time , and your life as you live it now is designed by accident or intention around this . you have habits and routines that accommodate your health needs . you have relationships with specialists . you have a relationship with your fiance that has evolved around the context of your current state of health . even if you assume that everything about becoming healthier will be better , it will still be different , and until you begin to experience you will be left with unanswerable questions . from where will i derive comfort how will the dynamics of my relationships change who am i without these health issues it is scary stuff , change , whether good , bad , or otherwise . but if you really want to be healthy , just take it day by day . nothing will change in an instant , and you will have time to figure out adapt to your new circumstances . good luck <end>

response: <start> i have tried my best not be shy but i always becomes shy when i meet someone new when i even met anyone . this sounds pretty typical , and may not be a symptom of a mental health issue . you could just be an introvert . when i am with my friends and kidding with each other i am easily offended and sometimes i keep overthinking and feeling sad and depressed all the day i need help . this sounds like it could be anxiety , and maybe a lack of coping skills for handling disagreements or hearing criticisms it does not sound like your friends are criticizing you , but you take offense to friendly jokes . if you have access to a therapist i suggest you give therapy a try , but if you can not do therapy , perhaps look for a debt workbook which can help you develop skills to overcome overthinking things and being easily offended . x b <end>

title: <start> what does a sex therapist do <end>
response: <start> it really depends . a lot of the time it is essentially marriage couples counseling that may or may not focus on sexual dysfunction one of the main causes of relationships failing is because of some type of sexual dysfunction , ie ed , vaginismus , etc . there are some clinicians who do specialize ex , bds community and work with specific and unique issues that are typically present in different relationship types . i am going to likely pursue getting that certification via aspect american association of sexuality educators , counselors , and therapists once i am done with my residency for licensure . the aspect website has a ton of info resources . also they have a yearly conference which is super interesting . <end>

title: <start> at what point might a therapist begin getting annoyed at a client due to lack of progress <end>
response: <start> the only way i become maybe a little frustrated is if it is been months and we are no further forward because the client will not engage and does not try , at that point i might say it probably is not the right time for them to be in therapy . that is not what it sounds like in your case , but is your therapist doing enough to help you do you have goals have you met some outcomes i . e . making sense of something previously not understood , finding positive coping skills it may just be that the hits keep coming and therapy is helping you cope with it , it is hard to see yourself moving forward when difficult situations keep arising . often there is progress but it is hard to see if small , has your therapist reflected on your progress do you have a good rapport <end>

response: <start> i am definitely putting in work , but i am very hard on myself when it comes to acknowledging small victories . while i have my long term goals for therapy , i do not really have any short term goals . making some would probably be a good idea , now that i think about it . i have a really good relationship with my therapist . i enjoy going to my sessions , i am very open with them , and they are very encouraging . they have done a lot for me , and they are good at helping me develop plans for treatment . my only problem is i just can not bring myself to believe that they actually care about me , and i am always self conscious and afraid that they hate me , and it is really damaging my ability to get the most out of my sessions . this is why i am so worried about not making enough progress i can not get the idea that they are annoyed at me , even though they have done nothing to give weight to that idea . i have talked about this a ton with them , they are very reassuring , but i do not know how to get past this wall that i have of trusting them . they always tell me that i am doing good work . they say that i am very insightful , and they talk about how my life might look different once i fix everything i am dealing with , so clearly they see hope in me . i just worry about every relationship in my life , and this is no different , so i just can not really bring myself to actually believe the words yet . <end>

title: <start> should i contact my so is doctor or therapist . <end>
response: <start> as a student therapist here is what i believe and know based on the ethics board . a therapist would not be able to say they are seeing your husband even if you know they are because of confidentiality and whippa laws . however if you know the therapist or office they are in and have away to contact them i would say something like this i know you can not tell me or give me indication that my husband is your client . however , if he is i would like you to know make note of these behaviors as i am concerned . list these behaviors thank you for taking the time to listen to me . because he has refused to let you go to therapy with him it is a difficult situation to maneuver through . they can not give you any information and they may not listen to you but , at least you voiced your concerns . if i was a fully licensed therapist and i received an email or message like that i would want to talk to my client about it especially if they are portraying a different scene . note i am only a student and have not passed my licensing exam or met with many clients yes so my advice is not foolproof or anything of the sort . if he is a danger to himself or others usually in a physical way then it is more acceptable to contact the therapist or doctor to let them know . but it is likely they will not tell you if your husband is actually a client or any other information . <end>

title: <start> what are some red flags when seeing a therapist <end>
response: <start> a couple of things come to mind personally , i will not see any therapist who believes that most problems are simply due to a chemical imbalance in the brain . if they just want to give me pills for my chemical imbalance , i am out of there . that said , i suspect this is typically a problem with psychiatrists and not with counselors . perhaps the more extreme problems require medication , but i do not want to see any therapist who is quick to medicate . i have heard that some counselors are pride based where maybe they just give you a pep talk and they pump you up and tell them that all of your problems are not your fault . i personally try to avoid this . that said , the best thing to do is probably to read reviews online and to choose someone who has a lot of good reviews . lastly and you might not like this one but a lot of churches want to see people healed and they will often have relationships with local counselors . . . and i think they kind of know who the good ones are . so i suppose you could also find a local non denominational church that has good reviews and give them a phone call and see who they might recommend . you might even be able to ask them specific questions about the therapist if they have a good relationship with them . <end>

title: <start> therapists reporting sexual assault in ny state <end>
response: <start> therapist here . we are mandated by law to report any disclosed abuse or neglect of a child , in the same way a physician is . so , if the mother or daughter brought this up in therapy , it would need to be reported . just because something is reported does not mean that anything happens aside from an initial investigation . if the child has no contact anymore , then it is likely the case would be closed quickly . the safety of the child becomes the priority . if a therapist chooses not to report abuse , they could face serious legal repercussions . it is not a personal thing , it is just part of the ethical oath we take when we become therapists . side note a yo child should not responsible for or in control of whether or not sexual abuse is reported . a child does not have the developmental capacity to make that kind of decision . additionally , if a child is a sexual molestation survivor and in therapy , the emotions and consequences of that abuse should be part of therapy . to not discuss this is a huge disservice to this child . <end>

title: <start> toxic work culture looking to get out but feel discouraged <end>
response: <start> keep in mind that websites like glassdoor are generally skewed to the negative . most folks that are happy with their jobs do not go on to websites like that to say how happy they are with their jobs . folks who are upset often use it as an outlet to vent so it may not be representative of any particular company . i have been in this situation before and i have jumped from frying pan into the fire on one occasion . if you know that you are not happy , you have to take the chance . if you end up somewhere that is the same or worse , you just keep looking . no work environment is perfect . no matter where you go there are always going to be some issues . so long as you are not miserable where you are and that the good outweighs the bad the majority of the time , then you are good . if you do not have that where you are , it is generally time to take a chance somewhere else . <end>

title: <start> parents want me to get a job at the same company as my ex . <end>
response: <start> i am not a therapist , but in my opinion it would be better for you to just tell your parents you will not be working there and that your decision is final rather than trying to persuade them to validate your concerns . i think by validating your own feelings believing they are important and acting as such , you kind of put other people in a position to either agree your feelings are important or decide they do not care . if someone decides they do not care when feelings are honestly and compassionately expressed then i do not think there is anything you can do about that , you just have to accept they have their own issues and leave it at that . one way i have found helpful with people who lack empathy is to empathise with their position why do they behave coldly out of what intentions are they acting are they just struggling like the rest of us do not get me wrong , i am not suggesting you put their struggles above your own , but i have found personally that empathising with those who hurt me has made it easier for me to walk away without holding on to anger and continuing to let the situation hurt me . <end>

title: <start> how can i improve having an anxious ambivalent attachment style <end>
response: <start> well now , this is a great question . there is some emerging evidence that family based therapy that targets the parent child relationship does shift attachment styles towards secure types . while this evidence is with adolescents , in my clinical anecdotal experience this works with adults as well . that being said , going to therapy should help . also there is an interesting phenomenon where people with anxious preoccupied styles that are in stable caring relationships tend to shift from anxious preoccupied towards security over time or they end . however , for this to happen it requires efforts form both partners and certainly helps if both partners can become aware of their patterns an essential part of couple therapy <end>

title: <start> how do i contact a therapist <end>
response: <start> i do not think there is a wrong way to contact your former therapist . and i would not worry about being seen as a waste . a lot of therapists have long term , reoccurring clients . maybe they take a year or several years off , but then come back as needed . you do not even necessarily need to tell her anything in your phone call or email , and you can get more into that after you start seeing them . just say something like hi , this is . i used to see you about years ago . i have got some stuff going on and i think it would be helpful to start seeing someone again . maybe say something about your availability and insurance if you have insurance . ps obligatory national suicide hotline . crisis text line <end>

title: <start> what do you call a person who wants to do too many things as a living <end>
response: <start> i had this same problem for years , i found the cure was to act , you do not wan t option paralysis to set in when having too many options causes you to choose none so you have to pick something today and start working on it , its very unlikely you actually have an aptitude for all of those things see the dunning trudger affect so try to start with whatever thing you believe you have the most aptitude or passion for or start by rejecting the things you have the least passion for you absolutely cannot make a living as a generalist in this day and age , the problem is if your hours a day assuming you sleep hours a night is spread across different things , you will absolutely not be able to compete with someone who spends their entire day as a photographer illustrator etc . having an interest in all these things is not bad , and a lot of great inspiration for artists comes from cross medium involvement , as a musician myself , some of my most profound inspiration has come from watching documentaries about painters or reading advice for writers , or experimenting with photography , but i have one central discipline , with hope for maybe exploring another sometimes in the future when i have a secure career . if i could suggest something for you , photography and music careers have huge boons if you are young , so if you wan t to be involved in either field i would suggest starting with either one of those first . <end>

title: <start> how can i help my partner who feels unfulfilled in his job and has confessed to having suicidal thoughts . <end>
response: <start> i have always dealt with constant low grade depression dysthymia , with some bouts of deeper depression peppered in there . twice , i had jobs i was very unhappy at i have never been suicidal , but unhappy to the point of calling my spouse or former bosses in tears and thought all would be solved by leaving that job . and it was . . . . . for a while . i have now been a homemaker for years this month and while i am very grateful every day for the ability to do this , i have had at least memorable bouts of heavy depression that came out of nowhere . his job may be a current factor affecting him , but his long term mental stability is still very fragile . no perfect job , or girlfriend , etc . is going to take the place of counseling for past issues or medication for a chemical imbalance . this is a fact , and for the sake of your own happiness and mental health , please consider the possibility that you may need to walk away to force him into a decision if he continues to refuse to seek help for himself . your life cannot be lived for someone else . i hope you are both able to find a solution . editing to add that i was in counseling for over two years and it has changed my life . i also regularly use a therapy light for s . a . d . chronic depression is a life ling condition and should be treated and maintained as such . <end>

title: <start> i m can not get over the she are not a virgin thought <end>
response: <start> you can not expect to change a lifetime of indoctrination by your parents and faith easily . it will take time . it is fantastic that you are taking the time to ask this question though . it sounds like the fact your partner may not be a virgin is only one of many thoughts you are having . i wonder if you would prefer to be with someone inexperienced so that your own level of experience does not show as much i wonder if you have sat down and spent some you thinking about why it is so important to you write down the pros and cons as honestly as possible . see how much your responses reflect your honest true feelings and how much they reflect things you were told growing up but do not believe . the fact your father encouraged you to visit a prostitute implies his own values around sex . also , take the time to write down your own personal values for what is important in a relationship . you can even order them in order of importance . generally though , i would say the first step to changing your thoughts is to notice them when they are happening , i notice i am thinking about whether she is a virgin or not . the next step would then be to challenge the thought i notice i am thinking about whether she is a virgin or not , however this is much less important to me than the type of person she is , and she is fantastic at x , y , z eg listening to me , being fun to be around etc . then focus on what is really important to you . if you think you need help with this then visiting a therapist may be of aid . i hope this helps a little and best of luck . <end>

response: <start> this is a pretty solid recommendation . there are a number of things that seeing a therapist would help with that i see in the post op . but seriously , i think you are on a great start by recognizing the issue already . i do fully agree that yes , with maturity , some of this will be less of an issue . it is been years for you but there is a lot of life left . personally , i have always been a bit of an old soul but me at was still so naive compared to the year old me . in addition , there is a lot of social construction about the importance of virginity and the emphasis that is placed upon in . there is also some biological aspect but that is rarely discussed but is a thing that exists . in addition to the question included in the comment above learning more about sex not from porn but the scientific study of sex and sexual issues i am willing to bet would help you to reconcile many of things you appear to be having trouble doing . <end>

title: <start> are therapists required to break confidentiality over abuse that happened years ago i am a minor <end>
response: <start> well , it depends a little bit on the definition of abuse in the state in which you live . some states define child abuse only as being possible from someone expected to protect them . however , in general , the answer would be yes , if you are a minor and been abused the therapist would be required to report this . it does not , however , have to be reported to your parent . but i would suggest generally that is probably a good idea . <end>

title: <start> psychiatrist diagnosed me within minutes and prescribed meds <end>
response: <start> psychiatrists are very different from therapists . they went to med school and can be classified as a medical doctor . the psychiatrists i have met through work generally see more patients in a shorter amount of time and prescribe meds rather than go really in depth into a person s background like a therapist might . there is pros and cons to each but usually the best bet is to work in tandem with a psychiatrist and therapist . did you have any sort of intake paperwork or assessment the psychiatrist might have seen that could be why the appointment was short if so . try the meds , adjustment period can be anywhere from weeks so you might have to be patient , but i also recommend seeing a therapist or continuing to see one if you already are to make sure your emotional needs outside of any organic chemical imbalance are being addressed . edit spelling <end>
